the first galaxies.

00:04:41.648 --> 00:04:46.256
Now, for thousands of years,
we have been studying the cosmos,

00:04:46.280 --> 00:04:48.934
we've been wondering
about our place in the universe.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.623
The ancient Greeks told us

00:04:50.647 --> 00:04:53.129
that the Earth was the center
of the universe.

00:04:53.153 --> 00:04:56.779
Five hundred years ago,
Copernicus displaced the Earth,

00:04:56.803 --> 00:04:59.594
and put the Sun
at the heart of the cosmos.

00:05:00.743 --> 00:05:02.797
And as we've learned over the centuries,

00:05:02.821 --> 00:05:05.539
since Galileo Galilei,
the Italian scientist,

00:05:05.563 --> 00:05:10.813
first turned, in that time, a two-inch,
very small telescope, to the sky,

00:05:10.837 --> 00:05:13.852
every time we have built
larger telescopes,

00:05:13.876 --> 00:05:16.075
we have learned something
about the universe;

00:05:16.099 --> 00:05:18.925
we've made discoveries, without exception.

00:05:20.866 --> 00:05:24.603
We've learned in the 20th century
that the universe is expanding

00:05:24.627 --> 00:05:29.351
and that our own solar system
is not at the center of that expansion.

00:05:29.715 --> 00:05:34.994
We know now that the universe
is made of about 100 billion galaxies

00:05:35.018 --> 00:05:36.668
that are visible to us,

00:05:36.692 --> 00:05:42.103
and each one of those galaxies
has 100 billion stars within it.

00:05:43.192 --> 00:05:46.054
So we're looking now
at the deepest image of the cosmos

00:05:46.078 --> 00:05:47.577
that's ever been taken.

00:05:47.973 --> 00:05:50.791
It was taken using
the Hubble Space Telescope,

00:05:50.815 --> 00:05:55.705
and by pointing the telescope at what
was previously a blank region of sky,

00:05:55.729 --> 00:05:57.328
before the launch of Hubble.

00:05:57.352 --> 00:05:59.615
And if you can imagine this tiny area,

00:05:59.639 --> 00:06:02.969
it's only one-fiftieth
of the size of the full moon.

00:06:02.993 --> 00:06:05.033
So, if you can imagine the full moon.

00:06:05.057 --> 00:06:09.195
And there are now 10,000 galaxies
visible within that image.

00:06:09.740 --> 00:06:14.418
And the faintness of those images
and the tiny size is only a result

00:06:14.442 --> 00:06:18.849
of the fact that those galaxies
are so far away, the vast distances.

00:06:18.873 --> 00:06:21.806
And each of those galaxies
may contain within it

00:06:21.830 --> 00:06:26.839
a few billion or even hundreds
of billions of individual stars.

00:06:27.549 --> 00:06:29.568
Telescopes are like time machines.

00:06:29.592 --> 00:06:34.055
So the farther back we look in space,
the further back we see in time.

00:06:34.428 --> 00:06:37.614
And they're like light buckets --
literally, they collect light.

00:06:37.638 --> 00:06:40.872
So larger the bucket,
the larger the mirror we have,

00:06:40.896 --> 00:06:44.306
the more light we can see,
and the farther back we can view.

00:06:45.568 --> 00:06:47.839
So, we've learned in the last century

00:06:47.863 --> 00:06:50.797
that there are exotic objects
in the universe -- black holes.

00:06:50.821 --> 00:06:53.598
We've even learned
that there's dark matter and dark energy

00:06:53.622 --> 00:06:54.833
that we can't see.

00:06:55.176 --> 00:06:58.734
So you're looking now
at an actual image of dark matter.

00:06:58.758 --> 00:06:59.908
(Laughter)

00:06:59.932 --> 00:07:02.575
You got it. Not all audiences get that.

00:07:02.599 --> 00:07:04.364
(Laughter)

00:07:04.388 --> 00:07:07.112
So the way we infer
the presence of dark matter --

00:07:07.136 --> 00:07:11.831
we can't see it -- but there's
an unmistakable tug, due to gravity.

00:07:13.260 --> 00:07:16.638
We now can look out,
we see this sea of galaxies

00:07:16.662 --> 00:07:18.439
in a universe that's expanding.

00:07:18.820 --> 00:07:22.123
What I do myself is to measure
the expansion of the universe,

00:07:22.147 --> 00:07:25.288
and one of the projects
that I carried out in the 1990s

00:07:25.312 --> 00:07:30.428
used the Hubble Space Telescope to measure
how fast the universe is expanding.

00:07:31.314 --> 00:07:35.280
We can now trace back to 14 billion years.

00:07:35.689 --> 00:07:40.025
We've learned over time
that stars have individual histories;

00:07:40.049 --> 00:07:42.978
that is, they have birth,
they have middle ages

00:07:43.002 --> 00:07:45.332
and some of them
even have dramatic deaths.

00:07:45.787 --> 00:07:51.902
So the embers from those stars actually
then form the new stars that we see,

00:07:51.926 --> 00:07:55.737
most of which turn out to have
planets going around them.

00:07:56.230 --> 00:08:00.265
And one of the really surprising results
in the last 20 years

00:08:00.289 --> 00:08:04.415
has been the discovery
of other planets going around other stars.

00:08:04.439 --> 00:08:06.345
These are called exoplanets.

00:08:06.369 --> 00:08:11.365
And until 1995, we didn't even know
the existence of any other planets,

00:08:11.389 --> 00:08:13.723
other than going around our own sun.

00:08:14.318 --> 00:08:20.739
But now, there are almost 2,000
other planets orbiting other stars

00:08:20.763 --> 00:08:23.323
that we can now detect,
measure masses for.

00:08:23.347 --> 00:08:27.019
There are 500 of those
that are multiple-planet systems.

00:08:27.043 --> 00:08:31.003
And there are 4,000 --
and still counting -- other candidates

00:08:31.027 --> 00:08:33.241
for planets orbiting other stars.

00:08:33.748 --> 00:08:36.721
They come in a bewildering variety
of different kinds.

00:08:37.092 --> 00:08:40.378
There are Jupiter-like
planets that are hot,

00:08:40.402 --> 00:08:44.660
there are other planets that are icy,
there are water worlds

00:08:44.684 --> 00:08:47.938
and there are rocky planets
like the Earth, so-called "super-Earths,"

00:08:47.962 --> 00:08:52.649
and there have even been planets
that have been speculated diamond worlds.

00:08:53.752 --> 00:08:58.707
So we know there's at least one planet,
our own Earth, in which there is life.

00:08:58.731 --> 00:09:02.891
We've even found planets
that are orbiting two stars.

00:09:02.915 --> 00:09:06.096
That's no longer the province
of science fiction.

00:09:07.169 --> 00:09:09.383
So around our own planet,
we know there's life,

00:09:09.407 --> 00:09:15.123
we've developed a complex life,
we now can question our own origins.

00:09:15.686 --> 00:09:19.906
And given all that we've discovered,
the overwhelming numbers now suggest

00:09:19.930 --> 00:09:24.002
that there may be millions, perhaps --
maybe even hundreds of millions --

00:09:24.026 --> 00:09:26.805
of other [planets]
that are close enough --

00:09:26.829 --> 00:09:30.119
just the right distance from their stars
that they're orbiting --

00:09:30.143 --> 00:09:35.679
to have the existence of liquid water
and maybe could potentially support life.

00:09:36.079 --> 00:09:40.253
So we marvel now at those odds,
the overwhelming odds,

00:09:40.277 --> 00:09:43.220
and the amazing thing
is that within the next decade,

00:09:43.244 --> 00:09:48.474
the GMT may be able to take spectra
of the atmospheres of those planets,

00:09:48.498 --> 00:09:52.010
and determine whether or not
they have the potential for life.

00:09:53.660 --> 00:09:55.440
So, what is the GMT project?

00:09:55.464 --> 00:09:57.338
It's an international project.

00:09:57.362 --> 00:10:03.211
It includes Australia, South Korea,
and I'm happy to say, being here in Rio,

00:10:03.235 --> 00:10:06.270
that the newest partner
in our telescope is Brazil.

00:10:06.783 --> 00:10:11.242
(Applause)

00:10:11.266 --> 00:10:16.056
It also includes a number of institutions
across the United States,

00:10:16.080 --> 00:10:19.176
including Harvard University,

00:10:19.200 --> 00:10:22.144
the Smithsonian
and the Carnegie Institutions,

00:10:22.168 --> 00:10:28.635
and the Universities of Arizona, Chicago,
Texas-Austin and Texas A&M University.

00:10:29.032 --> 00:10:30.919
It also involves Chile.

00:10:32.681 --> 00:10:35.893
So, the making of the mirrors
in this telescope is also fascinating

00:10:35.917 --> 00:10:37.282
in its own right.

00:10:37.306 --> 00:10:41.941
Take chunks of glass, melt them
in a furnace that is itself rotating.

00:10:42.709 --> 00:10:44.800
This happens underneath
the football stadium

00:10:44.824 --> 00:10:46.866
at the University of Arizona.

00:10:46.890 --> 00:10:49.826
It's tucked away under 52,000 seats.

00:10:49.850 --> 00:10:51.251
Nobody know it's happening.

00:10:51.696 --> 00:10:55.020
And there's essentially
a rotating cauldron.

00:10:55.044 --> 00:10:58.079
The mirrors are cast
and they're cooled very slowly,

00:10:58.103 --> 00:11:01.016
and then they're polished
to an exquisite precision.

00:11:01.595 --> 00:11:04.672
And so, if you think
about the precision of these mirrors,

00:11:04.696 --> 00:11:09.249
the bumps on the mirror,
over the entire 27 feet,

00:11:09.273 --> 00:11:12.952
amount to less
than one-millionth of an inch.

00:11:12.976 --> 00:11:14.500
So, can you visualize that?

00:11:15.047 --> 00:11:16.198
Ow!

00:11:16.222 --> 00:11:17.546
(Laughter)

00:11:17.570 --> 00:11:23.841
That's one five-thousandths
of the width of one of my hairs,

00:11:23.865 --> 00:11:26.002
over this entire 27 feet.

00:11:26.026 --> 00:11:27.896
It's a spectacular achievement.

00:11:27.920 --> 00:11:31.235
It's what allows us to have
the precision that we will have.

00:11:32.834 --> 00:11:35.251
So, what does that precision buy us?

00:11:35.801 --> 00:11:38.540
So the GMT, if you can imagine --

00:11:38.564 --> 00:11:43.013
if I were to hold up a coin,
which I just happen to have,

00:11:43.037 --> 00:11:48.028
and I look at the face of that coin,
I can see from here

00:11:48.052 --> 00:11:52.037
the writing on the coin;
I can see the face on that coin.

00:11:52.061 --> 00:11:55.175
My guess that even in the front row,
you can't see that.

00:11:55.603 --> 00:11:58.465
But if we were to turn
the Giant Magellan Telescope,

00:11:58.489 --> 00:12:01.862
all 80-feet diameter
that we see in this auditorium,

00:12:01.886 --> 00:12:04.955
and point it 200 miles away,

00:12:04.979 --> 00:12:10.847
if I were standing in São Paulo,
we could resolve the face of this coin.

00:12:10.871 --> 00:12:14.478
That's the extraordinary resolution
and power of this telescope.

00:12:15.719 --> 00:12:18.417
And if we were --

00:12:18.441 --> 00:12:22.311
(Applause)

00:12:22.335 --> 00:12:26.936
If an astronaut went up to the Moon,
a quarter of a million miles away,

00:12:26.960 --> 00:12:29.876
and lit a candle -- a single candle --

00:12:29.900 --> 00:12:32.710
then we would be able
to detect it, using the GMT.

00:12:33.305 --> 00:12:34.587
Quite extraordinary.

00:12:37.292 --> 00:12:42.973
This is a simulated image
of a cluster in a nearby galaxy.

00:12:42.997 --> 00:12:45.582
"Nearby" is astronomical,
it's all relative.

00:12:45.606 --> 00:12:48.109
It's tens of millions of light-years away.

00:12:48.133 --> 00:12:50.147
This is what this cluster would look like.

00:12:50.171 --> 00:12:52.339
So look at those four bright objects,

00:12:52.363 --> 00:12:56.370
and now lets compare it with a camera
on the Hubble Space Telescope.

00:12:56.394 --> 00:12:59.573
You can see faint detail
that starts to come through.

00:12:59.597 --> 00:13:05.892
And now finally -- and look how dramatic
this is -- this is what the GMT will see.

00:13:05.916 --> 00:13:08.286
So, keep your eyes on those
bright images again.

00:13:08.310 --> 00:13:12.728
This is what we see on one of the most
powerful existing telescopes on the Earth,

00:13:12.752 --> 00:13:15.633
and this, again, what the GMT will see.

00:13:16.512 --> 00:13:18.370
Extraordinary precision.

00:13:18.933 --> 00:13:20.255
So, where are we?

00:13:20.279 --> 00:13:23.461
We have now leveled the top
of the mountaintop in Chile.

00:13:23.485 --> 00:13:25.248
We blasted that off.

00:13:25.272 --> 00:13:27.991
We've tested and polished
the first mirror.

00:13:28.015 --> 00:13:30.604
We've cast the second
and the third mirrors.

00:13:30.628 --> 00:13:32.897
And we're about to cast the fourth mirror.

00:13:32.921 --> 00:13:34.808
We had a series of reviews this year,

00:13:34.832 --> 00:13:37.374
international panels
that came in and reviewed us,

00:13:37.398 --> 00:13:39.929
and said, "You're ready
to go to construction."

00:13:39.953 --> 00:13:43.302
And so we plan on building this telescope
with the first four mirrors.

00:13:43.326 --> 00:13:47.455
We want to get on the air quickly,
and be taking science data --

00:13:47.479 --> 00:13:52.058
what we astronomers call
"first light," in 2021.

00:13:52.989 --> 00:13:56.435
And the full telescope will be finished
in the middle of the next decade,

00:13:56.459 --> 00:13:57.855
with all seven mirrors.

00:13:58.500 --> 00:14:02.058
So we're now poised to look back
at the distant universe,

00:14:02.082 --> 00:14:03.390
the cosmic dawn.

00:14:03.762 --> 00:14:07.895
We'll be able to study other planets
in exquisite detail.

00:14:08.382 --> 00:14:12.119
But for me, one of the most
exciting things about building the GMT

00:14:12.143 --> 00:14:14.973
is the opportunity
to actually discover something

00:14:14.997 --> 00:14:18.267
that we don't know about --
that we can't even imagine at this point,

00:14:18.291 --> 00:14:19.933
something completely new.

00:14:20.671 --> 00:14:24.301
And my hope is that with the construction
of this and other facilities,

00:14:24.325 --> 00:14:29.535
that many young women and men
will be inspired to reach for the stars.

00:14:29.994 --> 00:14:31.266
Thank you very much.

00:14:31.290 --> 00:14:32.765
Obrigado.

00:14:32.789 --> 00:14:38.682
(Applause)

00:14:38.706 --> 00:14:40.308
Bruno Giussani: Thank you, Wendy.

00:14:40.332 --> 00:14:42.599
Stay with me, because
I have a question for you.

00:14:42.623 --> 00:14:45.020
You mentioned different facilities.

00:14:45.044 --> 00:14:49.897
So the Magellan Telescope is going up,
but also ALMA and others in Chile

00:14:49.921 --> 00:14:52.057
and elsewhere, including in Hawaii.

00:14:52.730 --> 00:14:56.806
Is it about cooperation
and complementarity, or about competition?

00:14:56.830 --> 00:15:00.552
I know there's competition in terms
of funding, but what about the science?

00:15:00.576 --> 00:15:03.793
Wendy Freedman: In terms of the science,
they're very complementary.

00:15:03.817 --> 00:15:06.844
The telescopes that are in space,
the telescopes on the ground,

00:15:06.868 --> 00:15:09.298
telescopes with different
wavelength capability,

00:15:09.322 --> 00:15:12.265
telescopes even that are similar,
but different instruments --

00:15:12.289 --> 00:15:16.035
they will all look at different parts
of the questions that we're asking.

00:15:16.059 --> 00:15:19.686
So when we discover other planets,
we'll be able to test those observations,

00:15:19.710 --> 00:15:21.798
we'll be able to measure the atmospheres,

00:15:21.822 --> 00:15:24.697
be able to look in space
with very high resolution.

00:15:24.721 --> 00:15:26.198
So, they're very complementary.

00:15:26.222 --> 00:15:28.459
You're right about
the funding, we compete;

00:15:28.483 --> 00:15:31.148
but scientifically,
it's very complementary.

00:15:31.172 --> 00:15:33.825
BG: Wendy, thank you very much
for coming to TEDGlobal.

00:15:33.849 --> 00:15:35.000
WF: Thank you.

00:15:35.024 --> 00:15:36.712
(Applause)

title: An invitation to men who want a better world for women
transcript: I will always remember the first time I met the girl in the blue uniform. I was eight at the time, living in the village with my grandmother, who was raising me and other children. Famine had hit my country of Zimbabwe, and we just didn't have enough to eat. We were hungry. And that's when the girl in the blue uniform came to my village with the United Nations to feed the children.As she handed me my porridge, I asked her why she was there, and without hesitation, she said, "As Africans, we must uplift all the people of Africa." I had absolutely no idea what she meant.(Laughter)But her words stuck with me.Two years later, famine hit my country for the second time. My grandmother had no choice but to send me to the city to live with an aunt I had never met before. So at the age of 10, I found myself in school for the very first time. And there, at the city school, I would experience what it was to be unequal. You see, in the village, we were all equal. But in the eyes and the minds of the other kids, I was not their equal. I couldn't speak English, and I was way behind in terms of reading and writing. But this feeling of inequality would get even more complex. Every school holiday spent back in the village with my grandmother made me consciously aware of the inequalities this incredible opportunity had created within my own family. Suddenly, I had much more than the rest of my village. And in their eyes, I was no longer their equal.I felt guilty. But I thought about the girl in the blue uniform, and I remember thinking, "That's who I want to be — someone like her, someone who uplifts other people." This childhood experience led me to the United Nations, and to my current role with UN Women, where we are addressing one of the greatest inequalities that affects more than half of the world's population — women and girls.Today, I want to share with you a simple idea that seeks to uplift all of us together. Eight months ago, under the visionary leadership of Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, head of UN Women, we launched a groundbreaking initiative called HeForShe, inviting men and boys from around the world to stand in solidarity with each other and with women, to create a shared vision for gender equality. This is an invitation for those who believe in equality for women and men, and those who don't yet know that they believe.The initiative is based on a simple idea: that what we share is much more powerful than what divides us. We all feel the same things. We all want the same things, even when those things sometimes remain unspoken. HeForShe is about uplifting all of us, women and men together. It's moving us towards an inflection point for gender equality.Imagine a blank page with one horizontal line splitting it in half. Now imagine that women are represented here, and men are represented here. In our current population, HeForShe is about moving the 3.2 billion men, one man at a time, across that line, so that ultimately, men can stand alongside women and be on the right side of history, making gender equality a reality in the 21st century.However, engaging men in the movement would prove quite controversial. Why invite men? They are the problem.(Laughter)In fact, men don't care, we were told.But something incredible happened when we launched HeForShe. In just three days, more than 100,000 men had signed up and committed to be agents of change for equality. Within that first week, at least one man in every single country in the world stood up to be counted, and within that same week, HeForShe created more than 1.2 billion conversations on social media. And that's when the emails started pouring in, sometimes as many as a thousand a day. We heard from a man out of Zimbabwe, who, after hearing about HeForShe, created a "husband school."(Laughter)He literally went around his village, hand-picking all of the men that were abusive to their partners, and committed to turn them into better husbands and fathers. In Pune, India, a youth advocate organized an innovative bicycle rally, mobilizing 700 cyclists to share the HeForShe messages within their own community.In another impact story, a man sent a very personal note of something that had happened in his own community. He wrote, "Dear Madam, I have lived all of my life next door to a man who continuously beats up his wife. Two weeks ago, I was listening to my radio, and your voice came on, and you spoke about something called the HeForShe, and the need for men to play their role. Within a few hours, I heard the woman cry again next door, but for the first time, I didn't just sit there. I felt compelled to do something, so I went over and I confronted the husband. Madam, it has been two weeks, and the woman has not cried since. Thank you for giving me a voice."(Applause)Personal impact stories such as these show that we are tapping into something within men, but getting to a world where women and men are equal is not just a matter of bringing men to the cause. We want concrete, systematic, structural change that can equalize the political, economic and social realities for women and men. We are asking men to make concrete actions, calling them to intervene at a personal level, to change their behavior. We are calling upon governments, businesses, universities, to change their policies. We want male leaders to become role models and change agents within their own institutions.Already, a number of prominent men and leaders have stepped up and made some concrete HeForShe commitments. In a few early success stories, a leading French hospitality company, Accor, has committed to eliminate the pay gap for all of its 180,000 employees by 2020.(Applause)The government of Sweden, under its current feminist government, has committed to close both the employment and the pay gap for all of its citizens within the current electoral term. In Japan, the University of Nagoya is building, as part of their HeForShe commitments, what will become one of Japan's leading gender-research centers.Now, eight months later, a movement is building. We are seeing men sign up from every single walk of life, and from every single corner in the world, from the United Nations' own Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to the Secretary-Generals of NATO and the EU Council, from the prime minister of Bhutan to the president of Sierra Leone.In Europe alone, all the male EU Commissioners and the members of Parliament of the Swedish and Iceland governments have signed up to be HeForShe. In fact, one in 20 men in Iceland has joined the movement. The rallying call of our passionate goodwill ambassador, Emma Watson, has garnered more than five billion media impressions, mobilizing hundreds and thousands of students around the world to create more than a hundred HeForShe student associations.Now this is the beginning of the vision that HeForShe has for the world that we want to see. Einstein once said, "A human being is part of the whole ... but he experiences himself, his thoughts and feelings, as something separate from the rest ... This delusion is a kind of prison for us ... Our task must be to free ourselves from this prison by widening our circle of compassion."If women and men are part of a greater whole, as Einstein suggests, it is my hope that HeForShe can help free us to realize that it is not our gender that defines us, but ultimately, our shared humanity. HeForShe is tapping into women's and men's dreams, the dreams that we have for ourselves, and the dreams that we have for our families, our children, friends, communities.So that's what it is about. HeForShe is about uplifting all of us together.Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:50.639 --> 00:00:52.417
to feed the children.

00:00:53.742 --> 00:00:56.321
As she handed me my porridge,

00:00:56.345 --> 00:00:59.606
I asked her why she was there,

00:00:59.630 --> 00:01:03.320
and without hesitation, she said,

00:01:03.344 --> 00:01:10.002
"As Africans, we must uplift
all the people of Africa."

00:01:11.663 --> 00:01:14.695
I had absolutely no idea what she meant.

00:01:14.719 --> 00:01:16.790
(Laughter)

00:01:16.814 --> 00:01:18.401
But her words stuck with me.

00:01:20.377 --> 00:01:21.933
Two years later,

00:01:21.957 --> 00:01:25.408
famine hit my country for the second time.

00:01:26.472 --> 00:01:30.933
My grandmother had no choice
but to send me to the city

00:01:30.957 --> 00:01:33.741
to live with an aunt
I had never met before.

00:01:35.107 --> 00:01:36.965
So at the age of 10,

00:01:36.989 --> 00:01:41.011
I found myself in school
for the very first time.

00:01:42.774 --> 00:01:45.417
And there, at the city school,

00:01:45.441 --> 00:01:49.472
I would experience
what it was to be unequal.

00:01:50.957 --> 00:01:52.735
You see, in the village,

00:01:52.759 --> 00:01:54.028
we were all equal.

00:01:55.052 --> 00:01:58.219
But in the eyes and the minds
of the other kids,

00:01:58.243 --> 00:02:00.178
I was not their equal.

00:02:01.123 --> 00:02:03.456
I couldn't speak English,

00:02:03.480 --> 00:02:07.789
and I was way behind
in terms of reading and writing.

00:02:09.155 --> 00:02:13.710
But this feeling of inequality
would get even more complex.

00:02:14.957 --> 00:02:16.719
Every school holiday

00:02:16.743 --> 00:02:19.878
spent back in the village
with my grandmother

00:02:19.902 --> 00:02:22.370
made me consciously aware

00:02:22.394 --> 00:02:25.933
of the inequalities
this incredible opportunity

00:02:25.957 --> 00:02:28.599
had created within my own family.

00:02:30.044 --> 00:02:34.282
Suddenly, I had much more
than the rest of my village.

00:02:35.695 --> 00:02:39.504
And in their eyes,
I was no longer their equal.

00:02:41.171 --> 00:02:42.401
I felt guilty.

00:02:44.488 --> 00:02:47.995
But I thought about the girl
in the blue uniform,

00:02:48.019 --> 00:02:50.282
and I remember thinking,

00:02:50.306 --> 00:02:53.115
"That's who I want to be --

00:02:53.139 --> 00:02:55.208
someone like her,

00:02:55.232 --> 00:02:58.662
someone who uplifts other people."

00:02:59.861 --> 00:03:04.933
This childhood experience
led me to the United Nations,

00:03:04.957 --> 00:03:07.584
and to my current role with UN Women,

00:03:07.608 --> 00:03:11.751
where we are addressing
one of the greatest inequalities

00:03:11.775 --> 00:03:15.720
that affects more than half
of the world's population --

00:03:15.744 --> 00:03:16.925
women and girls.

00:03:18.599 --> 00:03:20.440
Today, I want to share with you

00:03:20.464 --> 00:03:27.242
a simple idea that seeks to uplift
all of us together.

00:03:29.115 --> 00:03:30.829
Eight months ago,

00:03:30.853 --> 00:03:35.098
under the visionary leadership
of Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka,

00:03:35.122 --> 00:03:37.178
head of UN Women,

00:03:37.202 --> 00:03:40.203
we launched a groundbreaking initiative

00:03:40.227 --> 00:03:42.051
called HeForShe,

00:03:42.075 --> 00:03:45.464
inviting men and boys
from around the world

00:03:45.488 --> 00:03:49.806
to stand in solidarity
with each other and with women,

00:03:49.830 --> 00:03:53.369
to create a shared vision
for gender equality.

00:03:54.012 --> 00:03:58.933
This is an invitation
for those who believe in equality

00:03:58.957 --> 00:04:01.218
for women and men,

00:04:01.242 --> 00:04:04.805
and those who don't yet know
that they believe.

00:04:05.893 --> 00:04:09.933
The initiative is based on a simple idea:

00:04:09.957 --> 00:04:14.338
that what we share is much more powerful

00:04:14.362 --> 00:04:15.798
than what divides us.

00:04:16.663 --> 00:04:19.259
We all feel the same things.

00:04:19.283 --> 00:04:22.274
We all want the same things,

00:04:22.298 --> 00:04:26.560
even when those things
sometimes remain unspoken.

00:04:28.314 --> 00:04:31.036
HeForShe is about uplifting all of us,

00:04:31.060 --> 00:04:32.814
women and men together.

00:04:33.361 --> 00:04:37.694
It's moving us towards
an inflection point for gender equality.

00:04:38.957 --> 00:04:41.108
Imagine a blank page

00:04:41.132 --> 00:04:44.243
with one horizontal line
splitting it in half.

00:04:45.187 --> 00:04:49.361
Now imagine that women
are represented here,

00:04:49.385 --> 00:04:52.083
and men are represented here.

00:04:53.123 --> 00:04:55.233
In our current population,

00:04:55.257 --> 00:05:00.645
HeForShe is about moving
the 3.2 billion men,

00:05:00.669 --> 00:05:02.758
one man at a time,

00:05:02.782 --> 00:05:04.583
across that line,

00:05:04.607 --> 00:05:09.933
so that ultimately,
men can stand alongside women

00:05:09.957 --> 00:05:12.798
and be on the right side of history,

00:05:12.822 --> 00:05:18.242
making gender equality a reality
in the 21st century.

00:05:19.306 --> 00:05:24.088
However, engaging men in the movement
would prove quite controversial.

00:05:24.957 --> 00:05:27.806
Why invite men? They are the problem.

00:05:27.830 --> 00:05:28.988
(Laughter)

00:05:29.012 --> 00:05:31.980
In fact, men don't care, we were told.

00:05:33.345 --> 00:05:37.035
But something incredible happened
when we launched HeForShe.

00:05:38.298 --> 00:05:43.425
In just three days, more than 100,000 men

00:05:43.449 --> 00:05:48.806
had signed up and committed
to be agents of change for equality.

00:05:49.957 --> 00:05:56.385
Within that first week, at least one man
in every single country in the world

00:05:56.409 --> 00:05:59.202
stood up to be counted,

00:05:59.226 --> 00:06:01.575
and within that same week,

00:06:01.599 --> 00:06:08.012
HeForShe created more than
1.2 billion conversations on social media.

00:06:09.266 --> 00:06:13.567
And that's when the emails
started pouring in,

00:06:13.591 --> 00:06:17.639
sometimes as many as a thousand a day.

00:06:19.393 --> 00:06:22.448
We heard from a man out of Zimbabwe,

00:06:22.472 --> 00:06:25.139
who, after hearing about HeForShe,

00:06:25.163 --> 00:06:26.821
created a "husband school."

00:06:27.401 --> 00:06:29.694
(Laughter)

00:06:29.718 --> 00:06:32.670
He literally went around his village,

00:06:32.694 --> 00:06:36.956
hand-picking all of the men
that were abusive to their partners,

00:06:36.980 --> 00:06:41.345
and committed to turn them
into better husbands and fathers.

00:06:42.583 --> 00:06:48.646
In Pune, India, a youth advocate
organized an innovative bicycle rally,

00:06:48.671 --> 00:06:52.306
mobilizing 700 cyclists

00:06:52.330 --> 00:06:56.623
to share the HeForShe messages
within their own community.

00:06:57.663 --> 00:07:00.448
In another impact story,

00:07:00.472 --> 00:07:02.877
a man sent a very personal note

00:07:02.901 --> 00:07:05.901
of something that had happened
in his own community.

00:07:06.710 --> 00:07:09.353
He wrote,

00:07:09.377 --> 00:07:11.265
"Dear Madam,

00:07:11.289 --> 00:07:13.925
I have lived all of my life

00:07:13.949 --> 00:07:17.996
next door to a man
who continuously beats up his wife.

00:07:19.464 --> 00:07:21.003
Two weeks ago,

00:07:21.027 --> 00:07:23.734
I was listening to my radio,

00:07:23.758 --> 00:07:26.170
and your voice came on,

00:07:26.194 --> 00:07:30.714
and you spoke about something
called the HeForShe,

00:07:30.738 --> 00:07:33.618
and the need for men to play their role.

00:07:34.981 --> 00:07:40.663
Within a few hours, I heard
the woman cry again next door,

00:07:40.687 --> 00:07:43.107
but for the first time,

00:07:43.131 --> 00:07:45.124
I didn't just sit there.

00:07:45.148 --> 00:07:48.933
I felt compelled to do something,

00:07:48.957 --> 00:07:52.513
so I went over
and I confronted the husband.

00:07:53.652 --> 00:07:57.018
Madam, it has been two weeks,

00:07:57.042 --> 00:07:59.358
and the woman has not cried since.

00:07:59.867 --> 00:08:02.893
Thank you for giving me a voice."

00:08:02.917 --> 00:08:08.100
(Applause)

00:08:08.124 --> 00:08:11.933
Personal impact stories such as these

00:08:11.957 --> 00:08:16.298
show that we are tapping
into something within men,

00:08:16.322 --> 00:08:19.933
but getting to a world
where women and men are equal

00:08:19.957 --> 00:08:22.851
is not just a matter
of bringing men to the cause.

00:08:24.290 --> 00:08:31.274
We want concrete, systematic,
structural change that can equalize

00:08:31.298 --> 00:08:36.758
the political, economic
and social realities for women and men.

00:08:37.472 --> 00:08:40.527
We are asking men
to make concrete actions,

00:08:40.551 --> 00:08:43.671
calling them to intervene
at a personal level,

00:08:43.695 --> 00:08:45.614
to change their behavior.

00:08:46.123 --> 00:08:51.123
We are calling upon governments,
businesses, universities,

00:08:51.147 --> 00:08:53.147
to change their policies.

00:08:54.195 --> 00:08:58.377
We want male leaders to become role models

00:08:58.401 --> 00:09:01.877
and change agents
within their own institutions.

00:09:03.218 --> 00:09:07.655
Already, a number of prominent men
and leaders have stepped up

00:09:07.679 --> 00:09:10.123
and made some concrete
HeForShe commitments.

00:09:11.250 --> 00:09:14.733
In a few early success stories,

00:09:14.757 --> 00:09:18.297
a leading French
hospitality company, Accor,

00:09:18.321 --> 00:09:21.997
has committed to eliminate the pay gap

00:09:22.021 --> 00:09:26.822
for all of its 180,000 employees by 2020.

00:09:27.417 --> 00:09:30.965
(Applause)

00:09:30.989 --> 00:09:33.425
The government of Sweden,

00:09:33.449 --> 00:09:36.108
under its current feminist government,

00:09:36.132 --> 00:09:41.291
has committed to close
both the employment and the pay gap

00:09:41.315 --> 00:09:45.584
for all of its citizens
within the current electoral term.

00:09:46.957 --> 00:09:50.059
In Japan, the University of Nagoya

00:09:50.083 --> 00:09:53.338
is building, as part of
their HeForShe commitments,

00:09:53.362 --> 00:09:58.679
what will become one of Japan's
leading gender-research centers.

00:10:00.623 --> 00:10:03.130
Now, eight months later,

00:10:03.154 --> 00:10:05.091
a movement is building.

00:10:05.988 --> 00:10:10.933
We are seeing men sign up
from every single walk of life,

00:10:10.957 --> 00:10:14.307
and from every single corner in the world,

00:10:14.331 --> 00:10:18.513
from the United Nations' own
Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon

00:10:18.537 --> 00:10:24.155
to the Secretary-Generals of NATO
and the EU Council,

00:10:24.179 --> 00:10:26.756
from the prime minister of Bhutan

00:10:26.780 --> 00:10:28.882
to the president of Sierra Leone.

00:10:30.026 --> 00:10:34.144
In Europe alone,
all the male EU Commissioners

00:10:34.168 --> 00:10:38.264
and the members of Parliament
of the Swedish and Iceland governments

00:10:38.288 --> 00:10:40.699
have signed up to be HeForShe.

00:10:41.422 --> 00:10:47.215
In fact, one in 20 men in Iceland
has joined the movement.

00:10:48.639 --> 00:10:53.171
The rallying call of our passionate
goodwill ambassador, Emma Watson,

00:10:53.195 --> 00:10:57.124
has garnered more than
five billion media impressions,

00:10:57.148 --> 00:11:02.149
mobilizing hundreds and thousands
of students around the world

00:11:02.173 --> 00:11:06.561
to create more than a hundred
HeForShe student associations.

00:11:08.076 --> 00:11:13.275
Now this is the beginning
of the vision that HeForShe has

00:11:13.299 --> 00:11:14.980
for the world that we want to see.

00:11:17.037 --> 00:11:18.656
Einstein once said,

00:11:19.823 --> 00:11:24.457
"A human being is part of the whole ...

00:11:24.481 --> 00:11:27.196
but he experiences himself,

00:11:27.220 --> 00:11:29.291
his thoughts and feelings,

00:11:29.315 --> 00:11:31.794
as something separate from the rest ...

00:11:32.683 --> 00:11:35.960
This delusion
is a kind of prison for us ...

00:11:36.814 --> 00:11:41.774
Our task must be
to free ourselves from this prison

00:11:41.798 --> 00:11:45.194
by widening our circle of compassion."

00:11:46.940 --> 00:11:50.409
If women and men
are part of a greater whole,

00:11:50.433 --> 00:11:52.933
as Einstein suggests,

00:11:52.957 --> 00:11:58.210
it is my hope that HeForShe
can help free us to realize

00:11:58.234 --> 00:12:02.885
that it is not our gender that defines us,

00:12:02.909 --> 00:12:05.925
but ultimately, our shared humanity.

00:12:06.973 --> 00:12:11.466
HeForShe is tapping
into women's and men's dreams,

00:12:11.490 --> 00:12:14.504
the dreams that we have for ourselves,

00:12:14.528 --> 00:12:19.433
and the dreams that we have
for our families, our children,

00:12:19.457 --> 00:12:22.099
friends, communities.

00:12:23.036 --> 00:12:25.909
So that's what it is about.

00:12:26.734 --> 00:12:33.281
HeForShe is about uplifting
all of us together.

00:12:34.044 --> 00:12:35.203
Thank you.

00:12:35.227 --> 00:12:37.886
(Applause)

title: How the mysterious dark net is going mainstream
transcript: If you want to buy high-quality, low-price cocaine, there really is only one place to go, and that is the dark net anonymous markets.Now, you can't get to these sites with a normal browser — Chrome or Firefox — because they're on this hidden part of the Internet, known as Tor hidden services, where URLs are a string of meaningless numbers and letters that end in .onion, and which you access with a special browser called the Tor browser.Now, the Tor browser was originally a U.S. Naval intelligence project. It then became open source, and it allows anybody to browse the net without giving away their location. And it does this by encrypting your IP address and then routing it via several other computers around the world that use the same software. You can use it on the normal Internet, but it's also your key to the dark net. And because of this fiendishly clever encryption system, the 20 or 30 — we don't know exactly — thousand sites that operate there are incredibly difficult to shut down. It is a censorship-free world visited by anonymous users.Little wonder, then, that it's a natural place to go for anybody with something to hide, and that something, of course, need not be illegal. On the dark net, you will find whistle-blower sites, The New Yorker. You will find political activism blogs. You will find libraries of pirated books. But you'll also find the drugs markets, illegal pornography, commercial hacking services, and much more besides. Now, the dark net is one of the most interesting, exciting places anywhere on the net. And the reason is, because although innovation, of course, takes place in big businesses, takes place in world-class universities, it also takes place in the fringes, because those on the fringes — the pariahs, the outcasts — they're often the most creative, because they have to be. In this part of the Internet, you will not find a single lolcat, a single pop-up advert anywhere. And that's one of the reasons why I think many of you here will be on the dark net fairly soon.(Laughter)Not that I'm suggesting anyone in this audience would use it to go and procure high-quality narcotics. But let's say for a moment that you were.(Laughter)Bear with me. The first thing you will notice on signing up to one of these sites is how familiar it looks. Every single product — thousands of products — has a glossy, high-res image, a detailed product description, a price. There's a "Proceed to checkout" icon. There is even, most beautifully of all, a "Report this item" button.(Laughter)Incredible.You browse through the site, you make your choice, you pay with the crypto-currency bitcoin, you enter an address —  preferably not your home address — and you wait for your product to arrive in the post, which it nearly always does. And the reason it does is not because of the clever encryption. That's important. Something far simpler than that. It's the user reviews.(Laughter)You see, every single vendor on these sites uses a pseudonym, naturally enough, but they keep the same pseudonym to build up a reputation. And because it's easy for the buyer to change allegiance whenever they want, the only way of trusting a vendor is if they have a good history of positive feedback from other users of the site.And this introduction of competition and choice does exactly what the economists would predict. Prices tend to go down, product quality tends to go up, and the vendors are attentive, they're polite, they're consumer-centric, offering you all manner of special deals, one-offs, buy-one-get-one-frees, free delivery, to keep you happy.I spoke to Drugsheaven. Drugsheaven was offering excellent and consistent marijuana at a reasonable price. He had a very generous refund policy, detailed T's and C's, and good shipping times."Dear Drugsheaven," I wrote, via the internal emailing system that's also encrypted, of course. "I'm new here. Do you mind if I buy just one gram of marijuana?"A couple of hours later, I get a reply. They always reply."Hi there, thanks for your email. Starting small is a wise thing to do. I would, too, if I were you."(Laughter)"So no problem if you'd like to start with just one gram. I do hope we can do business together. Best wishes, Drugsheaven."(Laughter)I don't know why he had a posh English accent, but I assume he did.Now, this kind of consumer-centric attitude is the reason why, when I reviewed 120,000 pieces of feedback that had been left on one of these sites over a three-month period, 95 percent of them were five out of five. The customer, you see, is king. But what does that mean? Well, on the one hand, that means there are more drugs, more available, more easily, to more people. And by my reckoning, that is not a good thing. But, on the other hand, if you are going to take drugs, you have a reasonably good way of guaranteeing a certain level of purity and quality, which is incredibly important if you're taking drugs. And you can do so from the comfort of your own home, without the risks associated with buying on the streets.Now, as I said, you've got to be creative and innovative to survive in this marketplace. And the 20 or so sites that are currently in operation — by the way, they don't always work, they're not always perfect; the site that I showed you was shut down 18 months ago, but not before it had turned over a billion dollars' worth of trade. But these markets, because of the difficult conditions in which they are operating, the inhospitable conditions, are always innovating, always thinking of ways of getting smarter, more decentralized, harder to censor, and more customer-friendly.Let's take the payment system. You don't pay with your credit card, of course — that would lead directly back to you. So you use the crypto-currency bitcoin, which is easily exchanged for real-world currencies and gives quite a high degree of anonymity to its users.But at the beginning of these sites, people noticed a flaw. Some of the unscrupulous dealers were running away with peoples' bitcoin before they'd mailed the drugs out. The community came up with a solution, called multi-signature escrow payments. So on purchasing my item, I would send my bitcoin to a neutral, secure third digital wallet. The vendor, who would see that I'd sent it, would be confident that they could then send the product to me, and then when I received it, at least two of the three people engaged in the transaction — vendor, buyer, site administrator — would have to sign the transaction off with a unique digital signature, and then the money would be transferred.Brilliant! Elegant. It works.But then they realized there was a problem with bitcoin, because every bitcoin transaction is actually recorded publicly in a public ledger. So if you're clever, you can try and work out who's behind them. So they came up with a tumbling service. Hundreds of people send their bitcoin into one address, they're tumbled and jumbled up, and then the right amount is sent on to the right recipients, but they're different bitcoins: micro-laundering systems.(Laughter)It's incredible.Interested in what drugs are trending right now on the dark net markets? Check Grams, the search engine. You can even buy some advertising space.(Laughter)Are you an ethical consumer worried about what the drugs industry is doing? Yeah. One vendor will offer you fair trade organic cocaine.(Laughter)That's not being sourced from Colombian druglords, but Guatemalan farmers. They even promised to reinvest 20 percent of any profits into local education programs.(Laughter)There's even a mystery shopper.Now, whatever you think about the morality of these sites — and I submit that it's not actually an easy question — the creation of functioning, competitive, anonymous markets, where nobody knows who anybody else is, constantly at risk of being shut down by the authorities, is a staggering achievement, a phenomenal achievement. And it's that kind of innovation that's why those on the fringes are often the harbingers of what is to come.It's easy to forget that because of its short life, the Internet has actually changed many times over the last 30 years or so. It started in the '70s as a military project, morphed in the 1980s to an academic network, co-opted by commercial companies in the '90s, and then invaded by all of us via social media in the noughties, but I think it's going to change again. And I think things like the dark net markets — creative, secure, difficult to censor — I think that's the future.And the reason it's the future is because we're all worried about our privacy. Surveys consistently show concerns about privacy. The more time we spend online, the more we worry about them, and those surveys show our worries are growing. We're worried about what happens to our data. We're worried about who might be watching us.Since the revelations from Edward Snowden, there's been a huge increase in the number of people using various privacy-enhancing tools. There are now between two and three million daily users of the Tor browser, the majority of which use is perfectly legitimate, sometimes even mundane. And there are hundreds of activists around the world working on techniques and tools to keep you private online — default encrypted messaging services. Ethereum, which is a project which tries to link up the connected but unused hard drives of millions of computers around the world, to create a sort of distributed Internet that no one really controls. Now, we've had distributed computing before, of course. We use it for everything from Skype to the search for extraterrestrial life. But you add distributed computing and powerful encryption — that's very, very hard to censor and control. Another called MaidSafe works on similar principles. Another called Twister, and so on and so on.And here's the thing — the more of us join, the more interesting those sites become, and then the more of us join, and so on. And I think that's what's going to happen.In fact, it's already happening. The dark net is no longer a den for dealers and a hideout for whistle-blowers. It's already going mainstream. Just recently, the musician Aphex Twin released his album as a dark net site. Facebook has started a dark net site. A group of London architects have opened a dark net site for people worried about regeneration projects. Yes, the dark net is going mainstream, and I predict that fairly soon, every social media company, every major news outlet, and therefore most of you in this audience, will be using the dark net, too.So the Internet is about to get more interesting, more exciting, more innovative, more terrible, more destructive. That's good news if you care about liberty. It's good news if you care about freedom. It's good news if you care about democracy. It's also good news if you want to browse for illegal pornography and if you want to buy and sell drugs with impunity. Neither entirely dark, nor entirely light. It's not one side or the other that's going to win out, but both.Thank you very much, indeed.(Applause)

and which you access
