00:00:44.587 --> 00:00:46.032
called the Tor browser.

00:00:46.757 --> 00:00:51.333
Now, the Tor browser was originally
a U.S. Naval intelligence project.

00:00:51.357 --> 00:00:53.238
It then became open source,

00:00:53.262 --> 00:00:55.849
and it allows anybody to browse the net

00:00:55.873 --> 00:00:58.325
without giving away their location.

00:00:58.913 --> 00:01:02.453
And it does this
by encrypting your IP address

00:01:02.477 --> 00:01:06.253
and then routing it via several
other computers around the world

00:01:06.277 --> 00:01:08.616
that use the same software.

00:01:09.466 --> 00:01:11.733
You can use it on the normal Internet,

00:01:11.757 --> 00:01:15.472
but it's also your key to the dark net.

00:01:16.396 --> 00:01:19.466
And because of this fiendishly
clever encryption system,

00:01:19.490 --> 00:01:24.909
the 20 or 30 -- we don't know exactly --
thousand sites that operate there

00:01:24.933 --> 00:01:28.140
are incredibly difficult to shut down.

00:01:28.600 --> 00:01:34.053
It is a censorship-free world
visited by anonymous users.

00:01:35.226 --> 00:01:39.544
Little wonder, then,
that it's a natural place to go

00:01:39.568 --> 00:01:41.480
for anybody with something to hide,

00:01:41.504 --> 00:01:46.095
and that something, of course,
need not be illegal.

00:01:46.757 --> 00:01:48.596
On the dark net, you will find

00:01:48.620 --> 00:01:50.858
whistle-blower sites, The New Yorker.

00:01:51.183 --> 00:01:53.669
You will find political activism blogs.

00:01:53.693 --> 00:01:56.801
You will find libraries of pirated books.

00:01:56.825 --> 00:02:00.448
But you'll also find the drugs markets,

00:02:00.472 --> 00:02:04.577
illegal pornography,
commercial hacking services,

00:02:04.601 --> 00:02:06.198
and much more besides.

00:02:06.222 --> 00:02:12.032
Now, the dark net is one of the most
interesting, exciting places

00:02:12.056 --> 00:02:13.733
anywhere on the net.

00:02:13.757 --> 00:02:17.433
And the reason is, because
although innovation, of course,

00:02:17.457 --> 00:02:19.733
takes place in big businesses,

00:02:19.757 --> 00:02:22.156
takes place in world-class universities,

00:02:22.180 --> 00:02:24.733
it also takes place in the fringes,

00:02:24.757 --> 00:02:29.300
because those on the fringes --
the pariahs, the outcasts --

00:02:29.324 --> 00:02:32.561
they're often the most creative,
because they have to be.

00:02:33.577 --> 00:02:36.010
In this part of the Internet,

00:02:36.034 --> 00:02:38.313
you will not find a single lolcat,

00:02:38.337 --> 00:02:40.518
a single pop-up advert anywhere.

00:02:41.407 --> 00:02:43.820
And that's one of the reasons why I think

00:02:43.844 --> 00:02:47.533
many of you here will be
on the dark net fairly soon.

00:02:47.557 --> 00:02:49.557
(Laughter)

00:02:50.135 --> 00:02:53.427
Not that I'm suggesting
anyone in this audience would use it

00:02:53.451 --> 00:02:55.728
to go and procure high-quality narcotics.

00:02:56.363 --> 00:02:58.348
But let's say for a moment that you were.

00:02:58.372 --> 00:02:59.945
(Laughter)

00:03:00.398 --> 00:03:01.549
Bear with me.

00:03:02.826 --> 00:03:07.402
The first thing you will notice
on signing up to one of these sites

00:03:07.426 --> 00:03:09.011
is how familiar it looks.

00:03:10.257 --> 00:03:13.223
Every single product --

00:03:13.247 --> 00:03:15.111
thousands of products --

00:03:15.135 --> 00:03:19.151
has a glossy, high-res image,

00:03:19.175 --> 00:03:22.023
a detailed product description, a price.

00:03:22.372 --> 00:03:25.452
There's a "Proceed to checkout" icon.

00:03:25.476 --> 00:03:28.234
There is even, most beautifully of all,

00:03:28.258 --> 00:03:30.416
a "Report this item" button.

00:03:30.440 --> 00:03:33.147
(Laughter)

00:03:33.171 --> 00:03:35.097
Incredible.

00:03:35.121 --> 00:03:37.508
You browse through the site,
you make your choice,

00:03:37.532 --> 00:03:39.951
you pay with the crypto-currency bitcoin,

00:03:39.975 --> 00:03:43.004
you enter an address -- 
preferably not your home address --

00:03:43.028 --> 00:03:45.733
and you wait for your product
to arrive in the post,

00:03:45.757 --> 00:03:48.620
which it nearly always does.

00:03:49.239 --> 00:03:53.097
And the reason it does
is not because of the clever encryption.

00:03:53.121 --> 00:03:54.286
That's important.

00:03:54.632 --> 00:03:57.961
Something far simpler than that.

00:03:57.985 --> 00:03:59.210
It's the user reviews.

00:03:59.902 --> 00:04:01.217
(Laughter)

00:04:01.241 --> 00:04:05.012
You see, every single vendor
on these sites

00:04:05.036 --> 00:04:07.354
uses a pseudonym, naturally enough,

00:04:07.378 --> 00:04:11.171
but they keep the same pseudonym
to build up a reputation.

00:04:11.568 --> 00:04:16.868
And because it's easy for the buyer
to change allegiance whenever they want,

00:04:16.892 --> 00:04:21.165
the only way of trusting a vendor

00:04:21.189 --> 00:04:24.827
is if they have a good history
of positive feedback

00:04:24.851 --> 00:04:26.441
from other users of the site.

00:04:27.354 --> 00:04:31.831
And this introduction
of competition and choice

00:04:31.855 --> 00:04:36.124
does exactly what
the economists would predict.

00:04:37.304 --> 00:04:41.990
Prices tend to go down,
product quality tends to go up,

00:04:42.014 --> 00:04:44.387
and the vendors are attentive,

00:04:44.411 --> 00:04:46.842
they're polite, they're consumer-centric,

00:04:46.866 --> 00:04:51.178
offering you all manner
of special deals, one-offs,

00:04:51.202 --> 00:04:54.373
buy-one-get-one-frees, free delivery,

00:04:54.397 --> 00:04:55.581
to keep you happy.

00:04:56.911 --> 00:04:59.829
I spoke to Drugsheaven.

00:04:59.853 --> 00:05:05.743
Drugsheaven was offering
excellent and consistent marijuana

00:05:05.767 --> 00:05:07.309
at a reasonable price.

00:05:08.112 --> 00:05:11.921
He had a very generous refund policy,

00:05:11.945 --> 00:05:13.733
detailed T's and C's,

00:05:13.757 --> 00:05:15.169
and good shipping times.

00:05:15.566 --> 00:05:17.827
"Dear Drugsheaven," I wrote,

00:05:17.851 --> 00:05:21.665
via the internal emailing system
that's also encrypted, of course.

00:05:22.355 --> 00:05:26.496
"I'm new here. Do you mind
if I buy just one gram of marijuana?"

00:05:27.408 --> 00:05:29.532
A couple of hours later, I get a reply.

00:05:29.556 --> 00:05:30.742
They always reply.

00:05:31.188 --> 00:05:32.984
"Hi there, thanks for your email.

00:05:34.112 --> 00:05:39.380
Starting small is a wise thing to do.
I would, too, if I were you."

00:05:39.404 --> 00:05:41.166
(Laughter)

00:05:41.190 --> 00:05:44.311
"So no problem if you'd like to start
with just one gram.

00:05:44.335 --> 00:05:46.846
I do hope we can do business together.

00:05:46.870 --> 00:05:48.733
Best wishes, Drugsheaven."

00:05:48.757 --> 00:05:50.733
(Laughter)

00:05:50.757 --> 00:05:54.021
I don't know why he had a posh
English accent, but I assume he did.

00:05:56.237 --> 00:06:00.733
Now, this kind
of consumer-centric attitude

00:06:00.757 --> 00:06:06.193
is the reason why, when I reviewed
120,000 pieces of feedback

00:06:06.217 --> 00:06:10.197
that had been left on one of these sites
over a three-month period,

00:06:10.221 --> 00:06:13.350
95 percent of them were five out of five.

00:06:14.521 --> 00:06:17.062
The customer, you see, is king.

00:06:17.757 --> 00:06:18.967
But what does that mean?

00:06:18.991 --> 00:06:20.932
Well, on the one hand,

00:06:20.956 --> 00:06:24.990
that means there are more drugs,
more available, more easily,

00:06:25.014 --> 00:06:26.165
to more people.

00:06:26.757 --> 00:06:29.687
And by my reckoning,
that is not a good thing.

00:06:30.757 --> 00:06:34.470
But, on the other hand,
if you are going to take drugs,

00:06:34.494 --> 00:06:37.555
you have a reasonably good way

00:06:37.579 --> 00:06:41.993
of guaranteeing a certain level
of purity and quality,

00:06:42.017 --> 00:06:45.733
which is incredibly important
if you're taking drugs.

00:06:45.757 --> 00:06:48.875
And you can do so
from the comfort of your own home,

00:06:48.899 --> 00:06:53.086
without the risks associated
with buying on the streets.

00:06:53.919 --> 00:06:55.395
Now, as I said,

00:06:55.419 --> 00:06:59.521
you've got to be creative and innovative
to survive in this marketplace.

00:07:00.235 --> 00:07:03.329
And the 20 or so sites
that are currently in operation --

00:07:03.353 --> 00:07:07.058
by the way, they don't always work,
they're not always perfect;

00:07:07.082 --> 00:07:09.684
the site that I showed you
was shut down 18 months ago,

00:07:09.708 --> 00:07:14.859
but not before it had turned
over a billion dollars' worth of trade.

00:07:17.428 --> 00:07:18.581
But these markets,

00:07:18.605 --> 00:07:21.667
because of the difficult conditions
in which they are operating,

00:07:21.691 --> 00:07:23.179
the inhospitable conditions,

00:07:23.203 --> 00:07:26.551
are always innovating, always
thinking of ways of getting smarter,

00:07:26.575 --> 00:07:28.813
more decentralized, harder to censor,

00:07:28.837 --> 00:07:31.193
and more customer-friendly.

00:07:32.304 --> 00:07:33.733
Let's take the payment system.

00:07:34.341 --> 00:07:36.139
You don't pay with your credit card,

00:07:36.163 --> 00:07:38.508
of course -- that would lead
directly back to you.

00:07:38.532 --> 00:07:40.509
So you use the crypto-currency bitcoin,

00:07:40.533 --> 00:07:44.988
which is easily exchanged
for real-world currencies

00:07:45.012 --> 00:07:48.757
and gives quite a high degree
of anonymity to its users.

00:07:49.325 --> 00:07:52.252
But at the beginning of these sites,
people noticed a flaw.

00:07:52.276 --> 00:07:56.341
Some of the unscrupulous dealers
were running away with peoples' bitcoin

00:07:56.365 --> 00:07:58.170
before they'd mailed the drugs out.

00:07:59.113 --> 00:08:05.008
The community came up with a solution,
called multi-signature escrow payments.

00:08:07.093 --> 00:08:10.586
So on purchasing my item,

00:08:10.610 --> 00:08:13.636
I would send my bitcoin

00:08:13.660 --> 00:08:17.952
to a neutral, secure third digital wallet.

00:08:18.757 --> 00:08:21.346
The vendor, who would see
that I'd sent it,

00:08:21.370 --> 00:08:24.326
would be confident that they
could then send the product to me,

00:08:24.350 --> 00:08:25.733
and then when I received it,

00:08:25.757 --> 00:08:28.733
at least two of the three people
engaged in the transaction --

00:08:28.757 --> 00:08:31.297
vendor, buyer, site administrator --

00:08:31.321 --> 00:08:33.733
would have to sign the transaction off

00:08:33.757 --> 00:08:35.835
with a unique digital signature,

00:08:35.859 --> 00:08:37.834
and then the money would be transferred.

00:08:38.221 --> 00:08:39.521
Brilliant!

00:08:39.545 --> 00:08:40.696
Elegant.

00:08:40.720 --> 00:08:41.871
It works.

00:08:42.835 --> 00:08:45.486
But then they realized there was
a problem with bitcoin,

00:08:45.510 --> 00:08:47.211
because every bitcoin transaction

00:08:47.235 --> 00:08:49.733
is actually recorded publicly
in a public ledger.

00:08:49.757 --> 00:08:53.034
So if you're clever, you can try
and work out who's behind them.

00:08:53.058 --> 00:08:56.343
So they came up with a tumbling service.

00:08:56.367 --> 00:08:59.758
Hundreds of people send
their bitcoin into one address,

00:08:59.782 --> 00:09:01.757
they're tumbled and jumbled up,

00:09:01.781 --> 00:09:05.571
and then the right amount
is sent on to the right recipients,

00:09:05.595 --> 00:09:07.417
but they're different bitcoins:

00:09:07.441 --> 00:09:09.131
micro-laundering systems.

00:09:09.155 --> 00:09:10.689
(Laughter)

00:09:10.713 --> 00:09:11.869
It's incredible.

00:09:11.893 --> 00:09:17.086
Interested in what drugs are trending
right now on the dark net markets?

00:09:17.110 --> 00:09:19.187
Check Grams, the search engine.

00:09:19.211 --> 00:09:21.376
You can even buy some advertising space.

00:09:21.400 --> 00:09:23.465
(Laughter)

00:09:23.489 --> 00:09:28.427
Are you an ethical consumer worried
about what the drugs industry is doing?

00:09:29.022 --> 00:09:30.173
Yeah.

00:09:30.550 --> 00:09:33.944
One vendor will offer you
fair trade organic cocaine.

00:09:33.968 --> 00:09:35.110
(Laughter)

00:09:35.134 --> 00:09:38.429
That's not being sourced
from Colombian druglords,

00:09:38.453 --> 00:09:39.882
but Guatemalan farmers.

00:09:39.906 --> 00:09:43.218
They even promised to reinvest
20 percent of any profits

00:09:43.242 --> 00:09:45.032
into local education programs.

00:09:45.056 --> 00:09:46.078
(Laughter)

00:09:46.102 --> 00:09:48.081
There's even a mystery shopper.

00:09:48.894 --> 00:09:52.278
Now, whatever you think
about the morality of these sites --

00:09:52.302 --> 00:09:55.617
and I submit that it's not
actually an easy question --

00:09:55.641 --> 00:10:01.143
the creation of functioning,
competitive, anonymous markets,

00:10:01.167 --> 00:10:03.733
where nobody knows who anybody else is,

00:10:03.757 --> 00:10:06.856
constantly at risk of being shut down
by the authorities,

00:10:06.880 --> 00:10:09.414
is a staggering achievement,

00:10:09.438 --> 00:10:11.476
a phenomenal achievement.

00:10:12.537 --> 00:10:15.951
And it's that kind of innovation

00:10:15.975 --> 00:10:18.733
that's why those on the fringes

00:10:18.757 --> 00:10:21.604
are often the harbingers
of what is to come.

00:10:22.318 --> 00:10:24.422
It's easy to forget

00:10:24.446 --> 00:10:26.508
that because of its short life,

00:10:26.532 --> 00:10:30.179
the Internet has actually
changed many times

00:10:30.203 --> 00:10:31.733
over the last 30 years or so.

00:10:31.757 --> 00:10:34.733
It started in the '70s
as a military project,

00:10:34.757 --> 00:10:38.733
morphed in the 1980s
to an academic network,

00:10:38.757 --> 00:10:41.219
co-opted by commercial
companies in the '90s,

00:10:41.243 --> 00:10:44.698
and then invaded by all of us
via social media in the noughties,

00:10:44.722 --> 00:10:46.651
but I think it's going to change again.

00:10:47.137 --> 00:10:49.733
And I think things
like the dark net markets --

00:10:49.757 --> 00:10:53.733
creative, secure, difficult to censor --

00:10:53.757 --> 00:10:55.359
I think that's the future.

00:10:56.887 --> 00:10:58.515
And the reason it's the future

00:10:58.539 --> 00:11:01.207
is because we're all worried
about our privacy.

00:11:01.231 --> 00:11:04.456
Surveys consistently show
concerns about privacy.

00:11:04.480 --> 00:11:08.439
The more time we spend online,
the more we worry about them,

00:11:08.463 --> 00:11:10.733
and those surveys show
our worries are growing.

00:11:10.757 --> 00:11:12.873
We're worried about
what happens to our data.

00:11:12.897 --> 00:11:15.006
We're worried about
who might be watching us.

00:11:15.030 --> 00:11:17.598
Since the revelations from Edward Snowden,

00:11:17.622 --> 00:11:20.068
there's been a huge increase
in the number of people

00:11:20.092 --> 00:11:23.184
using various privacy-enhancing tools.

00:11:23.208 --> 00:11:26.445
There are now between two
and three million daily users

00:11:26.469 --> 00:11:27.744
of the Tor browser,

00:11:27.768 --> 00:11:32.935
the majority of which use
is perfectly legitimate,

00:11:32.959 --> 00:11:34.718
sometimes even mundane.

00:11:35.616 --> 00:11:38.767
And there are hundreds of activists
around the world

00:11:38.791 --> 00:11:44.057
working on techniques and tools
to keep you private online --

00:11:45.069 --> 00:11:47.550
default encrypted messaging services.

00:11:47.574 --> 00:11:51.597
Ethereum, which is a project
which tries to link up

00:11:51.621 --> 00:11:56.699
the connected but unused hard drives
of millions of computers around the world,

00:11:56.723 --> 00:12:00.594
to create a sort of distributed Internet
that no one really controls.

00:12:00.618 --> 00:12:03.511
Now, we've had distributed
computing before, of course.

00:12:03.535 --> 00:12:07.733
We use it for everything from Skype
to the search for extraterrestrial life.

00:12:07.757 --> 00:12:12.246
But you add distributed computing
and powerful encryption --

00:12:12.270 --> 00:12:16.157
that's very, very hard
to censor and control.

00:12:16.583 --> 00:12:19.396
Another called MaidSafe
works on similar principles.

00:12:19.420 --> 00:12:22.868
Another called Twister,
and so on and so on.

00:12:23.354 --> 00:12:25.344
And here's the thing --

00:12:25.368 --> 00:12:26.832
the more of us join,

00:12:26.856 --> 00:12:29.307
the more interesting those sites become,

00:12:29.331 --> 00:12:31.819
and then the more of us join, and so on.

00:12:32.226 --> 00:12:34.251
And I think that's what's going to happen.

00:12:34.275 --> 00:12:36.423
In fact, it's already happening.

00:12:36.447 --> 00:12:40.323
The dark net is no longer
a den for dealers

00:12:40.347 --> 00:12:42.914
and a hideout for whistle-blowers.

00:12:42.938 --> 00:12:44.625
It's already going mainstream.

00:12:45.656 --> 00:12:52.230
Just recently, the musician Aphex Twin
released his album as a dark net site.

00:12:52.254 --> 00:12:56.207
Facebook has started a dark net site.

00:12:56.231 --> 00:12:59.864
A group of London architects
have opened a dark net site

00:12:59.888 --> 00:13:02.733
for people worried
about regeneration projects.

00:13:02.757 --> 00:13:05.330
Yes, the dark net is going mainstream,

00:13:05.354 --> 00:13:08.971
and I predict that fairly soon,
every social media company,

00:13:08.995 --> 00:13:10.430
every major news outlet,

00:13:10.454 --> 00:13:13.538
and therefore most of you
in this audience,

00:13:13.562 --> 00:13:15.918
will be using the dark net, too.

00:13:16.900 --> 00:13:19.929
So the Internet is about to get
more interesting,

00:13:19.953 --> 00:13:22.733
more exciting, more innovative,

00:13:22.757 --> 00:13:24.482
more terrible,

00:13:24.506 --> 00:13:25.860
more destructive.

00:13:27.098 --> 00:13:29.371
That's good news
if you care about liberty.

00:13:29.395 --> 00:13:31.365
It's good news if you care about freedom.

00:13:31.389 --> 00:13:33.508
It's good news if you care
about democracy.

00:13:33.532 --> 00:13:34.910
It's also good news

00:13:34.934 --> 00:13:37.380
if you want to browse
for illegal pornography

00:13:37.404 --> 00:13:39.733
and if you want to buy and sell drugs

00:13:39.757 --> 00:13:41.050
with impunity.

00:13:41.834 --> 00:13:45.733
Neither entirely dark, nor entirely light.

00:13:45.757 --> 00:13:49.434
It's not one side or the other
that's going to win out, but both.

00:13:50.310 --> 00:13:52.198
Thank you very much, indeed.

00:13:52.198 --> 00:13:55.908
(Applause)

title: The mathematician who cracked Wall Street
transcript: Chris Anderson: You were something of a mathematical phenom. You had already taught at Harvard and MIT at a young age. And then the NSA came calling. What was that about?Jim Simons: Well the NSA — that's the National Security Agency — they didn't exactly come calling. They had an operation at Princeton, where they hired mathematicians to attack secret codes and stuff like that. And I knew that existed. And they had a very good policy, because you could do half your time at your own mathematics, and at least half your time working on their stuff. And they paid a lot. So that was an irresistible pull. So, I went there.CA: You were a code-cracker.JS: I was.CA: Until you got fired.JS: Well, I did get fired. Yes.CA: How come?JS: Well, how come? I got fired because, well, the Vietnam War was on, and the boss of bosses in my organization was a big fan of the war and wrote a New York Times article, a magazine section cover story, about how we would win in Vietnam. And I didn't like that war, I thought it was stupid. And I wrote a letter to the Times, which they published, saying not everyone who works for Maxwell Taylor, if anyone remembers that name, agrees with his views. And I gave my own views ...CA: Oh, OK. I can see that would —JS: ... which were different from General Taylor's. But in the end, nobody said anything. But then, I was 29 years old at this time, and some kid came around and said he was a stringer from Newsweek magazine and he wanted to interview me and ask what I was doing about my views. And I told him, "I'm doing mostly mathematics now, and when the war is over, then I'll do mostly their stuff." Then I did the only intelligent thing I'd done that day — I told my local boss that I gave that interview. And he said, "What'd you say?" And I told him what I said. And then he said, "I've got to call Taylor." He called Taylor; that took 10 minutes. I was fired five minutes after that.CA: OK.JS: But it wasn't bad.CA: It wasn't bad, because you went on to Stony Brook and stepped up your mathematical career. You started working with this man here. Who is this?JS: Oh, [Shiing-Shen] Chern. Chern was one of the great mathematicians of the century. I had known him when I was a graduate student at Berkeley. And I had some ideas, and I brought them to him and he liked them. Together, we did this work which you can easily see up there. There it is.CA: It led to you publishing a famous paper together. Can you explain at all what that work was?JS: No.(Laughter)JS: I mean, I could explain it to somebody.(Laughter)CA: How about explaining this?JS: But not many. Not many people.CA: I think you told me it had something to do with spheres, so let's start here.JS: Well, it did, but I'll say about that work — it did have something to do with that, but before we get to that — that work was good mathematics. I was very happy with it; so was Chern. It even started a little sub-field that's now flourishing. But, more interestingly, it happened to apply to physics, something we knew nothing about — at least I knew nothing about physics, and I don't think Chern knew a heck of a lot. And about 10 years after the paper came out, a guy named Ed Witten in Princeton started applying it to string theory and people in Russia started applying it to what's called "condensed matter." Today, those things in there called Chern-Simons invariants have spread through a lot of physics. And it was amazing. We didn't know any physics. It never occurred to me that it would be applied to physics. But that's the thing about mathematics — you never know where it's going to go.CA: This is so incredible. So, we've been talking about how evolution shapes human minds that may or may not perceive the truth. Somehow, you come up with a mathematical theory, not knowing any physics, discover two decades later that it's being applied to profoundly describe the actual physical world. How can that happen?JS: God knows.(Laughter)But there's a famous physicist named [Eugene] Wigner, and he wrote an essay on the unreasonable effectiveness of mathematics. Somehow, this mathematics, which is rooted in the real world in some sense — we learn to count, measure, everyone would do that — and then it flourishes on its own. But so often it comes back to save the day. General relativity is an example. [Hermann] Minkowski had this geometry, and Einstein realized, "Hey! It's the very thing in which I can cast general relativity." So, you never know. It is a mystery. It is a mystery.CA: So, here's a mathematical piece of ingenuity. Tell us about this.JS: Well, that's a ball — it's a sphere, and it has a lattice around it — you know, those squares. What I'm going to show here was originally observed by [Leonhard] Euler, the great mathematician, in the 1700s. And it gradually grew to be a very important field in mathematics: algebraic topology, geometry. That paper up there had its roots in this. So, here's this thing: it has eight vertices, 12 edges, six faces. And if you look at the difference — vertices minus edges plus faces — you get two. OK, well, two. That's a good number. Here's a different way of doing it — these are triangles covering — this has 12 vertices and 30 edges and 20 faces, 20 tiles. And vertices minus edges plus faces still equals two. And in fact, you could do this any which way — cover this thing with all kinds of polygons and triangles and mix them up. And you take vertices minus edges plus faces — you'll get two. Here's a different shape. This is a torus, or the surface of a doughnut: 16 vertices covered by these rectangles, 32 edges, 16 faces. Vertices minus edges comes out to be zero. It'll always come out to zero. Every time you cover a torus with squares or triangles or anything like that, you're going to get zero. So, this is called the Euler characteristic. And it's what's called a topological invariant. It's pretty amazing. No matter how you do it, you're always get the same answer. So that was the first sort of thrust, from the mid-1700s, into a subject which is now called algebraic topology.CA: And your own work took an idea like this and moved it into higher-dimensional theory, higher-dimensional objects, and found new invariances?JS: Yes. Well, there were already higher-dimensional invariants: Pontryagin classes — actually, there were Chern classes. There were a bunch of these types of invariants. I was struggling to work on one of them and model it sort of combinatorially, instead of the way it was typically done, and that led to this work and we uncovered some new things. But if it wasn't for Mr. Euler — who wrote almost 70 volumes of mathematics and had 13 children, who he apparently would dandle on his knee while he was writing — if it wasn't for Mr. Euler, there wouldn't perhaps be these invariants.CA: OK, so that's at least given us a flavor of that amazing mind in there. Let's talk about Renaissance. Because you took that amazing mind and having been a code-cracker at the NSA, you started to become a code-cracker in the financial industry. I think you probably didn't buy efficient market theory. Somehow you found a way of creating astonishing returns over two decades. The way it's been explained to me, what's remarkable about what you did wasn't just the size of the returns, it's that you took them with surprisingly low volatility and risk, compared with other hedge funds. So how on earth did you do this, Jim?JS: I did it by assembling a wonderful group of people. When I started doing trading, I had gotten a little tired of mathematics. I was in my late 30s, I had a little money. I started trading and it went very well. I made quite a lot of money with pure luck. I mean, I think it was pure luck. It certainly wasn't mathematical modeling. But in looking at the data, after a while I realized: it looks like there's some structure here. And I hired a few mathematicians, and we started making some models — just the kind of thing we did back at IDA [Institute for Defense Analyses]. You design an algorithm, you test it out on a computer. Does it work? Doesn't it work? And so on.CA: Can we take a look at this? Because here's a typical graph of some commodity. I look at that, and I say, "That's just a random, up-and-down walk — maybe a slight upward trend over that whole period of time." How on earth could you trade looking at that, and see something that wasn't just random?JS: In the old days — this is kind of a graph from the old days, commodities or currencies had a tendency to trend. Not necessarily the very light trend you see here, but trending in periods. And if you decided, OK, I'm going to predict today, by the average move in the past 20 days — maybe that would be a good prediction, and I'd make some money. And in fact, years ago, such a system would work — not beautifully, but it would work. You'd make money, you'd lose money, you'd make money. But this is a year's worth of days, and you'd make a little money during that period. It's a very vestigial system.CA: So you would test a bunch of lengths of trends in time and see whether, for example, a 10-day trend or a 15-day trend was predictive of what happened next.JS: Sure, you would try all those things and see what worked best. Trend-following would have been great in the '60s, and it was sort of OK in the '70s. By the '80s, it wasn't.CA: Because everyone could see that. So, how did you stay ahead of the pack?JS: We stayed ahead of the pack by finding other approaches — shorter-term approaches to some extent. The real thing was to gather a tremendous amount of data — and we had to get it by hand in the early days. We went down to the Federal Reserve and copied interest rate histories and stuff like that, because it didn't exist on computers. We got a lot of data. And very smart people — that was the key. I didn't really know how to hire people to do fundamental trading. I had hired a few — some made money, some didn't make money. I couldn't make a business out of that. But I did know how to hire scientists, because I have some taste in that department. So, that's what we did. And gradually these models got better and better, and better and better.CA: You're credited with doing something remarkable at Renaissance, which is building this culture, this group of people, who weren't just hired guns who could be lured away by money. Their motivation was doing exciting mathematics and science.JS: Well, I'd hoped that might be true. But some of it was money.CA: They made a lot of money.JS: I can't say that no one came because of the money. I think a lot of them came because of the money. But they also came because it would be fun.CA: What role did machine learning play in all this?JS: In a certain sense, what we did was machine learning. You look at a lot of data, and you try to simulate different predictive schemes, until you get better and better at it. It doesn't necessarily feed back on itself the way we did things. But it worked.CA: So these different predictive schemes can be really quite wild and unexpected. I mean, you looked at everything, right? You looked at the weather, length of dresses, political opinion.JS: Yes, length of dresses we didn't try.CA: What sort of things?JS: Well, everything. Everything is grist for the mill — except hem lengths. Weather, annual reports, quarterly reports, historic data itself, volumes, you name it. Whatever there is. We take in terabytes of data a day. And store it away and massage it and get it ready for analysis. You're looking for anomalies. You're looking for — like you said, the efficient market hypothesis is not correct.CA: But any one anomaly might be just a random thing. So, is the secret here to just look at multiple strange anomalies, and see when they align?JS: Any one anomaly might be a random thing; however, if you have enough data you can tell that it's not. You can see an anomaly that's persistent for a sufficiently long time — the probability of it being random is not high. But these things fade after a while; anomalies can get washed out. So you have to keep on top of the business.CA: A lot of people look at the hedge fund industry now and are sort of ... shocked by it, by how much wealth is created there, and how much talent is going into it. Do you have any worries about that industry, and perhaps the financial industry in general? Kind of being on a runaway train that's — I don't know — helping increase inequality? How would you champion what's happening in the hedge fund industry?JS: I think in the last three or four years, hedge funds have not done especially well. We've done dandy, but the hedge fund industry as a whole has not done so wonderfully. The stock market has been on a roll, going up as everybody knows, and price-earnings ratios have grown. So an awful lot of the wealth that's been created in the last — let's say, five or six years — has not been created by hedge funds. People would ask me, "What's a hedge fund?" And I'd say, "One and 20." Which means — now it's two and 20 — it's two percent fixed fee and 20 percent of profits. Hedge funds are all different kinds of creatures.CA: Rumor has it you charge slightly higher fees than that.JS: We charged the highest fees in the world at one time. Five and 44, that's what we charge.CA: Five and 44. So five percent flat, 44 percent of upside. You still made your investors spectacular amounts of money.JS: We made good returns, yes. People got very mad: "How can you charge such high fees?" I said, "OK, you can withdraw." But "How can I get more?" was what people were —(Laughter)But at a certain point, as I think I told you, we bought out all the investors because there's a capacity to the fund.CA: But should we worry about the hedge fund industry attracting too much of the world's great mathematical and other talent to work on that, as opposed to the many other problems in the world?JS: Well, it's not just mathematical. We hire astronomers and physicists and things like that. I don't think we should worry about it too much. It's still a pretty small industry. And in fact, bringing science into the investing world has improved that world. It's reduced volatility. It's increased liquidity. Spreads are narrower because people are trading that kind of stuff. So I'm not too worried about Einstein going off and starting a hedge fund.CA: You're at a phase in your life now where you're actually investing, though, at the other end of the supply chain — you're actually boosting mathematics across America. This is your wife, Marilyn. You're working on philanthropic issues together. Tell me about that.JS: Well, Marilyn started — there she is up there, my beautiful wife — she started the foundation about 20 years ago. I think '94. I claim it was '93, she says it was '94, but it was one of those two years.(Laughter)We started the foundation, just as a convenient way to give charity. She kept the books, and so on. We did not have a vision at that time, but gradually a vision emerged — which was to focus on math and science, to focus on basic research. And that's what we've done. Six years ago or so, I left Renaissance and went to work at the foundation. So that's what we do.CA: And so Math for America is basically investing in math teachers around the country, giving them some extra income, giving them support and coaching. And really trying to make that more effective and make that a calling to which teachers can aspire.JS: Yeah — instead of beating up the bad teachers, which has created morale problems all through the educational community, in particular in math and science, we focus on celebrating the good ones and giving them status. Yeah, we give them extra money, 15,000 dollars a year. We have 800 math and science teachers in New York City in public schools today, as part of a core. There's a great morale among them. They're staying in the field. Next year, it'll be 1,000 and that'll be 10 percent of the math and science teachers in New York [City] public schools.(Applause)CA: Jim, here's another project that you've supported philanthropically: Research into origins of life, I guess. What are we looking at here? JS: Well, I'll save that for a second. And then I'll tell you what you're looking at. Origins of life is a fascinating question. How did we get here? Well, there are two questions: One is, what is the route from geology to biology — how did we get here? And the other question is, what did we start with? What material, if any, did we have to work with on this route? Those are two very, very interesting questions. The first question is a tortuous path from geology up to RNA or something like that — how did that all work? And the other, what do we have to work with? Well, more than we think. So what's pictured there is a star in formation. Now, every year in our Milky Way, which has 100 billion stars, about two new stars are created. Don't ask me how, but they're created. And it takes them about a million years to settle out. So, in steady state, there are about two million stars in formation at any time. That one is somewhere along this settling-down period. And there's all this crap sort of circling around it, dust and stuff. And it'll form probably a solar system, or whatever it forms. But here's the thing — in this dust that surrounds a forming star have been found, now, significant organic molecules. Molecules not just like methane, but formaldehyde and cyanide — things that are the building blocks — the seeds, if you will — of life. So, that may be typical. And it may be typical that planets around the universe start off with some of these basic building blocks. Now does that mean there's going to be life all around? Maybe. But it's a question of how tortuous this path is from those frail beginnings, those seeds, all the way to life. And most of those seeds will fall on fallow planets.CA: So for you, personally, finding an answer to this question of where we came from, of how did this thing happen, that is something you would love to see.JS: Would love to see. And like to know — if that path is tortuous enough, and so improbable, that no matter what you start with, we could be a singularity. But on the other hand, given all this organic dust that's floating around, we could have lots of friends out there. It'd be great to know.CA: Jim, a couple of years ago, I got the chance to speak with Elon Musk, and I asked him the secret of his success, and he said taking physics seriously was it. Listening to you, what I hear you saying is taking math seriously, that has infused your whole life. It's made you an absolute fortune, and now it's allowing you to invest in the futures of thousands and thousands of kids across America and elsewhere. Could it be that science actually works? That math actually works?JS: Well, math certainly works. Math certainly works. But this has been fun. Working with Marilyn and giving it away has been very enjoyable.CA: I just find it — it's an inspirational thought to me, that by taking knowledge seriously, so much more can come from it. So thank you for your amazing life, and for coming here to TED.Thank you.Jim Simons!(Applause)

00:00:12.775 --> 00:00:15.609
Chris Anderson: You were something
of a mathematical phenom.

00:00:15.633 --> 00:00:18.697
You had already taught at Harvard
and MIT at a young age.

00:00:18.721 --> 00:00:20.911
And then the NSA came calling.

00:00:21.422 --> 00:00:22.626
What was that about?

00:00:23.165 --> 00:00:27.088
Jim Simons: Well the NSA --
that's the National Security Agency --

00:00:27.112 --> 00:00:29.081
they didn't exactly come calling.

00:00:29.423 --> 00:00:33.897
They had an operation at Princeton,
where they hired mathematicians

00:00:33.921 --> 00:00:36.863
to attack secret codes
and stuff like that.

00:00:37.252 --> 00:00:38.924
And I knew that existed.

00:00:39.273 --> 00:00:41.453
And they had a very good policy,

00:00:41.477 --> 00:00:45.327
because you could do half your time
at your own mathematics,

00:00:45.351 --> 00:00:48.835
and at least half your time
working on their stuff.

00:00:49.517 --> 00:00:50.991
And they paid a lot.

00:00:51.015 --> 00:00:54.066
So that was an irresistible pull.

00:00:54.090 --> 00:00:56.002
So, I went there.

00:00:56.026 --> 00:00:57.364
CA: You were a code-cracker.

00:00:57.388 --> 00:00:58.554
JS: I was.

00:00:58.578 --> 00:00:59.735
CA: Until you got fired.

00:00:59.759 --> 00:01:01.342
JS: Well, I did get fired. Yes.

00:01:01.366 --> 00:01:02.611
CA: How come?

00:01:03.238 --> 00:01:04.571
JS: Well, how come?

00:01:05.569 --> 00:01:10.525
I got fired because,
well, the Vietnam War was on,

00:01:10.549 --> 00:01:16.287
and the boss of bosses in my organization
was a big fan of the war

00:01:16.311 --> 00:01:20.706
and wrote a New York Times article,
a magazine section cover story,

00:01:20.730 --> 00:01:22.500
about how we would win in Vietnam.

00:01:22.524 --> 00:01:25.653
And I didn't like that war,
I thought it was stupid.

00:01:25.677 --> 00:01:28.342
And I wrote a letter to the Times,
which they published,

00:01:28.366 --> 00:01:32.380
saying not everyone
who works for Maxwell Taylor,

00:01:32.404 --> 00:01:37.090
if anyone remembers that name,
agrees with his views.

00:01:37.511 --> 00:01:39.169
And I gave my own views ...

00:01:39.193 --> 00:01:41.357
CA: Oh, OK. I can see that would --

00:01:41.381 --> 00:01:43.936
JS: ... which were different
from General Taylor's.

00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:45.866
But in the end, nobody said anything.

00:01:45.890 --> 00:01:49.591
But then, I was 29 years old at this time,
and some kid came around

00:01:49.615 --> 00:01:52.703
and said he was a stringer
from Newsweek magazine

00:01:52.727 --> 00:01:58.094
and he wanted to interview me
and ask what I was doing about my views.

00:01:58.118 --> 00:02:02.017
And I told him, "I'm doing
mostly mathematics now,

00:02:02.041 --> 00:02:05.414
and when the war is over,
then I'll do mostly their stuff."

00:02:06.081 --> 00:02:08.906
Then I did the only
intelligent thing I'd done that day --

00:02:08.930 --> 00:02:13.087
I told my local boss
that I gave that interview.

00:02:13.111 --> 00:02:14.570
And he said, "What'd you say?"

00:02:14.594 --> 00:02:16.060
And I told him what I said.

00:02:16.084 --> 00:02:18.399
And then he said,
"I've got to call Taylor."

00:02:18.423 --> 00:02:20.800
He called Taylor; that took 10 minutes.

00:02:20.824 --> 00:02:23.086
I was fired five minutes after that.

00:02:23.548 --> 00:02:24.770
CA: OK.

00:02:24.794 --> 00:02:25.945
JS: But it wasn't bad.

00:02:25.969 --> 00:02:28.462
CA: It wasn't bad,
because you went on to Stony Brook

00:02:28.486 --> 00:02:31.619
and stepped up your mathematical career.

00:02:31.643 --> 00:02:34.095
You started working with this man here.

00:02:34.119 --> 00:02:35.283
Who is this?

00:02:36.310 --> 00:02:37.722
JS: Oh, [Shiing-Shen] Chern.

00:02:37.746 --> 00:02:40.850
Chern was one of the great
mathematicians of the century.

00:02:40.874 --> 00:02:46.107
I had known him when
I was a graduate student at Berkeley.

00:02:46.131 --> 00:02:48.002
And I had some ideas,

00:02:48.026 --> 00:02:50.473
and I brought them to him
and he liked them.

00:02:50.497 --> 00:02:57.123
Together, we did this work
which you can easily see up there.

00:02:57.147 --> 00:02:58.297
There it is.

00:02:59.156 --> 00:03:02.762
CA: It led to you publishing
a famous paper together.

00:03:02.786 --> 00:03:06.024
Can you explain at all what that work was?

00:03:06.986 --> 00:03:08.144
JS: No.

00:03:08.168 --> 00:03:10.442
(Laughter)

00:03:10.924 --> 00:03:12.988
JS: I mean, I could
explain it to somebody.

00:03:13.012 --> 00:03:15.087
(Laughter)

00:03:15.111 --> 00:03:16.975
CA: How about explaining this?

00:03:16.999 --> 00:03:19.728
JS: But not many. Not many people.

00:03:21.102 --> 00:03:23.916
CA: I think you told me
it had something to do with spheres,

00:03:23.940 --> 00:03:25.802
so let's start here.

00:03:25.826 --> 00:03:29.426
JS: Well, it did,
but I'll say about that work --

00:03:29.450 --> 00:03:32.650
it did have something to do with that,
but before we get to that --

00:03:32.674 --> 00:03:36.214
that work was good mathematics.

00:03:36.238 --> 00:03:38.730
I was very happy with it; so was Chern.

00:03:39.868 --> 00:03:44.044
It even started a little sub-field
that's now flourishing.

00:03:44.596 --> 00:03:49.890
But, more interestingly,
it happened to apply to physics,

00:03:49.914 --> 00:03:54.209
something we knew nothing about --
at least I knew nothing about physics,

00:03:54.233 --> 00:03:56.515
and I don't think Chern
knew a heck of a lot.

00:03:56.539 --> 00:04:00.502
And about 10 years
after the paper came out,

00:04:00.526 --> 00:04:05.006
a guy named Ed Witten in Princeton
started applying it to string theory

00:04:05.030 --> 00:04:09.882
and people in Russia started applying it
to what's called "condensed matter."

00:04:09.906 --> 00:04:14.799
Today, those things in there
called Chern-Simons invariants

00:04:14.823 --> 00:04:16.688
have spread through a lot of physics.

00:04:16.712 --> 00:04:17.886
And it was amazing.

00:04:17.910 --> 00:04:19.275
We didn't know any physics.

00:04:19.672 --> 00:04:22.526
It never occurred to me
that it would be applied to physics.

00:04:22.550 --> 00:04:26.338
But that's the thing about mathematics --
you never know where it's going to go.

00:04:26.362 --> 00:04:27.854
CA: This is so incredible.

00:04:27.878 --> 00:04:32.242
So, we've been talking about
how evolution shapes human minds

00:04:32.266 --> 00:04:34.774
that may or may not perceive the truth.

00:04:34.798 --> 00:04:38.111
Somehow, you come up
with a mathematical theory,

00:04:38.135 --> 00:04:39.983
not knowing any physics,

00:04:40.007 --> 00:04:42.505
discover two decades later
that it's being applied

00:04:42.529 --> 00:04:45.560
to profoundly describe
the actual physical world.

00:04:45.584 --> 00:04:46.737
How can that happen?

00:04:46.761 --> 00:04:47.918
JS: God knows.

00:04:47.942 --> 00:04:50.052
(Laughter)

00:04:50.807 --> 00:04:53.957
But there's a famous physicist
named [Eugene] Wigner,

00:04:53.981 --> 00:04:59.569
and he wrote an essay on the unreasonable
effectiveness of mathematics.

00:04:59.593 --> 00:05:03.545
Somehow, this mathematics,
which is rooted in the real world

00:05:03.569 --> 00:05:08.564
in some sense -- we learn to count,
measure, everyone would do that --

00:05:08.588 --> 00:05:10.418
and then it flourishes on its own.

00:05:10.934 --> 00:05:13.775
But so often it comes
back to save the day.

00:05:14.251 --> 00:05:16.429
General relativity is an example.

00:05:16.453 --> 00:05:19.570
[Hermann] Minkowski had this geometry,
and Einstein realized,

00:05:19.594 --> 00:05:23.441
"Hey! It's the very thing
in which I can cast general relativity."

00:05:23.465 --> 00:05:26.577
So, you never know. It is a mystery.

00:05:27.014 --> 00:05:28.231
It is a mystery.

00:05:28.255 --> 00:05:31.551
CA: So, here's a mathematical
piece of ingenuity.

00:05:31.575 --> 00:05:32.917
Tell us about this.

00:05:32.941 --> 00:05:38.865
JS: Well, that's a ball -- it's a sphere,
and it has a lattice around it --

00:05:38.889 --> 00:05:40.462
you know, those squares.

00:05:42.655 --> 00:05:47.561
What I'm going to show here was
originally observed by [Leonhard] Euler,

00:05:47.585 --> 00:05:49.839
the great mathematician, in the 1700s.

00:05:50.181 --> 00:05:55.362
And it gradually grew to be
a very important field in mathematics:

00:05:55.386 --> 00:05:57.720
algebraic topology, geometry.

00:05:58.997 --> 00:06:03.361
That paper up there had its roots in this.

00:06:03.385 --> 00:06:05.219
So, here's this thing:

00:06:05.243 --> 00:06:09.695
it has eight vertices,
12 edges, six faces.

00:06:09.719 --> 00:06:13.549
And if you look at the difference --
vertices minus edges plus faces --

00:06:13.573 --> 00:06:14.725
you get two.

00:06:14.749 --> 00:06:16.968
OK, well, two. That's a good number.

00:06:16.992 --> 00:06:21.240
Here's a different way of doing it --
these are triangles covering --

00:06:21.264 --> 00:06:25.841
this has 12 vertices and 30 edges

00:06:25.865 --> 00:06:30.060
and 20 faces, 20 tiles.

00:06:30.534 --> 00:06:35.125
And vertices minus edges
plus faces still equals two.

00:06:35.149 --> 00:06:37.996
And in fact, you could do this
any which way --

00:06:38.020 --> 00:06:41.418
cover this thing with all kinds
of polygons and triangles

00:06:41.442 --> 00:06:42.762
and mix them up.

00:06:42.786 --> 00:06:46.065
And you take vertices minus edges
plus faces -- you'll get two.

00:06:46.089 --> 00:06:47.700
Here's a different shape.

00:06:48.438 --> 00:06:53.688
This is a torus, or the surface
of a doughnut: 16 vertices

00:06:53.712 --> 00:06:57.956
covered by these rectangles,
32 edges, 16 faces.

00:06:58.488 --> 00:07:01.172
Vertices minus edges comes out to be zero.

00:07:01.196 --> 00:07:02.671
It'll always come out to zero.

00:07:02.695 --> 00:07:07.005
Every time you cover a torus
with squares or triangles

00:07:07.029 --> 00:07:10.964
or anything like that,
you're going to get zero.

00:07:12.472 --> 00:07:14.862
So, this is called
the Euler characteristic.

00:07:14.886 --> 00:07:18.335
And it's what's called
a topological invariant.

00:07:18.807 --> 00:07:19.963
It's pretty amazing.

00:07:19.987 --> 00:07:22.778
No matter how you do it,
you're always get the same answer.

00:07:22.802 --> 00:07:29.101
So that was the first sort of thrust,
from the mid-1700s,

00:07:29.125 --> 00:07:32.894
into a subject which is now called
algebraic topology.

00:07:32.918 --> 00:07:35.901
CA: And your own work
took an idea like this and moved it

00:07:35.925 --> 00:07:38.374
into higher-dimensional theory,

00:07:38.398 --> 00:07:41.486
higher-dimensional objects,
and found new invariances?

00:07:41.510 --> 00:07:46.153
JS: Yes. Well, there were already
higher-dimensional invariants:

00:07:46.177 --> 00:07:50.634
Pontryagin classes --
actually, there were Chern classes.

00:07:50.658 --> 00:07:54.206
There were a bunch
of these types of invariants.

00:07:54.230 --> 00:07:58.365
I was struggling to work on one of them

00:07:58.389 --> 00:08:02.592
and model it sort of combinatorially,

00:08:02.616 --> 00:08:05.638
instead of the way it was typically done,

00:08:05.662 --> 00:08:10.021
and that led to this work
and we uncovered some new things.

00:08:10.045 --> 00:08:13.546
But if it wasn't for Mr. Euler --

00:08:13.570 --> 00:08:17.551
who wrote almost 70 volumes of mathematics

00:08:17.575 --> 00:08:19.306
and had 13 children,

00:08:19.330 --> 00:08:25.772
who he apparently would dandle on his knee
while he was writing --

00:08:25.796 --> 00:08:31.570
if it wasn't for Mr. Euler, there wouldn't
perhaps be these invariants.

00:08:32.115 --> 00:08:36.212
CA: OK, so that's at least given us
a flavor of that amazing mind in there.

00:08:36.762 --> 00:08:38.305
Let's talk about Renaissance.

00:08:38.329 --> 00:08:44.185
Because you took that amazing mind
and having been a code-cracker at the NSA,

00:08:44.209 --> 00:08:47.438
you started to become a code-cracker
in the financial industry.

00:08:47.462 --> 00:08:50.152
I think you probably didn't buy
efficient market theory.

00:08:50.176 --> 00:08:56.563
Somehow you found a way of creating
astonishing returns over two decades.

00:08:56.587 --> 00:08:58.258
The way it's been explained to me,

00:08:58.282 --> 00:09:01.781
what's remarkable about what you did
wasn't just the size of the returns,

00:09:01.805 --> 00:09:05.688
it's that you took them
with surprisingly low volatility and risk,

00:09:05.712 --> 00:09:07.536
compared with other hedge funds.

00:09:07.560 --> 00:09:09.489
So how on earth did you do this, Jim?

00:09:10.029 --> 00:09:14.140
JS: I did it by assembling
a wonderful group of people.

00:09:14.164 --> 00:09:18.120
When I started doing trading, I had
gotten a little tired of mathematics.

00:09:18.144 --> 00:09:22.067
I was in my late 30s,
I had a little money.

00:09:22.091 --> 00:09:24.600
I started trading and it went very well.

00:09:25.021 --> 00:09:27.769
I made quite a lot of money
with pure luck.

00:09:27.793 --> 00:09:29.459
I mean, I think it was pure luck.

00:09:29.483 --> 00:09:31.592
It certainly wasn't mathematical modeling.

00:09:31.616 --> 00:09:35.447
But in looking at the data,
after a while I realized:

00:09:35.471 --> 00:09:38.024
it looks like there's some structure here.

00:09:38.048 --> 00:09:41.745
And I hired a few mathematicians,
and we started making some models --

00:09:41.769 --> 00:09:46.034
just the kind of thing we did back
at IDA [Institute for Defense Analyses].

00:09:46.058 --> 00:09:48.891
You design an algorithm,
you test it out on a computer.

00:09:48.915 --> 00:09:51.081
Does it work? Doesn't it work? And so on.

00:09:51.401 --> 00:09:52.880
CA: Can we take a look at this?

00:09:52.904 --> 00:09:57.445
Because here's a typical graph
of some commodity.

00:09:58.445 --> 00:10:02.486
I look at that, and I say,
"That's just a random, up-and-down walk --

00:10:02.510 --> 00:10:05.372
maybe a slight upward trend
over that whole period of time."

00:10:05.396 --> 00:10:07.509
How on earth could you trade
looking at that,

00:10:07.533 --> 00:10:09.859
and see something that wasn't just random?

00:10:09.883 --> 00:10:13.130
JS: In the old days -- this is
kind of a graph from the old days,

00:10:13.154 --> 00:10:17.438
commodities or currencies
had a tendency to trend.

00:10:17.462 --> 00:10:23.517
Not necessarily the very light trend
you see here, but trending in periods.

00:10:23.541 --> 00:10:27.597
And if you decided, OK,
I'm going to predict today,

00:10:27.621 --> 00:10:32.589
by the average move in the past 20 days --

00:10:32.613 --> 00:10:35.720
maybe that would be a good prediction,
and I'd make some money.

00:10:35.744 --> 00:10:41.352
And in fact, years ago,
such a system would work --

00:10:41.376 --> 00:10:43.767
not beautifully, but it would work.

00:10:43.791 --> 00:10:46.300
You'd make money, you'd lose
money, you'd make money.

00:10:46.324 --> 00:10:48.522
But this is a year's worth of days,

00:10:48.546 --> 00:10:52.787
and you'd make a little money
during that period.

00:10:53.842 --> 00:10:55.800
It's a very vestigial system.

00:10:56.483 --> 00:11:00.012
CA: So you would test
a bunch of lengths of trends in time

00:11:00.036 --> 00:11:02.472
and see whether, for example,

00:11:02.496 --> 00:11:05.977
a 10-day trend or a 15-day trend
was predictive of what happened next.

00:11:06.001 --> 00:11:12.763
JS: Sure, you would try all those things
and see what worked best.

00:11:13.473 --> 00:11:16.823
Trend-following would
have been great in the '60s,

00:11:16.847 --> 00:11:18.979
and it was sort of OK in the '70s.

00:11:19.003 --> 00:11:20.876
By the '80s, it wasn't.

00:11:20.900 --> 00:11:23.717
CA: Because everyone could see that.

00:11:23.741 --> 00:11:26.523
So, how did you stay ahead of the pack?

00:11:27.004 --> 00:11:33.136
JS: We stayed ahead of the pack
by finding other approaches --

00:11:33.160 --> 00:11:35.901
shorter-term approaches to some extent.

00:11:37.065 --> 00:11:40.412
The real thing was to gather
a tremendous amount of data --

00:11:40.436 --> 00:11:44.014
and we had to get it by hand
in the early days.

00:11:44.038 --> 00:11:47.504
We went down to the Federal Reserve
and copied interest rate histories

00:11:47.528 --> 00:11:50.793
and stuff like that,
because it didn't exist on computers.

00:11:50.817 --> 00:11:52.460
We got a lot of data.

00:11:52.484 --> 00:11:56.644
And very smart people -- that was the key.

00:11:57.421 --> 00:12:01.197
I didn't really know how to hire
people to do fundamental trading.

00:12:01.707 --> 00:12:04.656
I had hired a few -- some made money,
some didn't make money.

00:12:04.680 --> 00:12:06.560
I couldn't make a business out of that.

00:12:06.584 --> 00:12:08.626
But I did know how to hire scientists,

00:12:08.650 --> 00:12:12.039
because I have some taste
in that department.

00:12:12.063 --> 00:12:13.901
So, that's what we did.

00:12:13.925 --> 00:12:17.156
And gradually these models
got better and better,

00:12:17.180 --> 00:12:18.515
and better and better.

00:12:18.539 --> 00:12:21.753
CA: You're credited with doing
something remarkable at Renaissance,

00:12:21.777 --> 00:12:24.378
which is building this culture,
this group of people,

00:12:24.402 --> 00:12:27.544
who weren't just hired guns
who could be lured away by money.

00:12:27.568 --> 00:12:31.480
Their motivation was doing
exciting mathematics and science.

00:12:31.818 --> 00:12:34.217
JS: Well, I'd hoped that might be true.

00:12:34.241 --> 00:12:37.821
But some of it was money.

00:12:37.845 --> 00:12:39.238
CA: They made a lot of money.

00:12:39.262 --> 00:12:41.799
JS: I can't say that no one came
because of the money.

00:12:41.823 --> 00:12:44.076
I think a lot of them
came because of the money.

00:12:44.100 --> 00:12:46.121
But they also came
because it would be fun.

00:12:46.145 --> 00:12:48.633
CA: What role did machine learning
play in all this?

00:12:48.657 --> 00:12:51.721
JS: In a certain sense,
what we did was machine learning.

00:12:52.837 --> 00:12:59.128
You look at a lot of data, and you try
to simulate different predictive schemes,

00:12:59.152 --> 00:13:01.334
until you get better and better at it.

00:13:01.358 --> 00:13:05.125
It doesn't necessarily feed back on itself
the way we did things.

00:13:05.149 --> 00:13:07.458
But it worked.

00:13:08.108 --> 00:13:12.167
CA: So these different predictive schemes
can be really quite wild and unexpected.

00:13:12.191 --> 00:13:14.105
I mean, you looked at everything, right?

00:13:14.129 --> 00:13:17.446
You looked at the weather,
length of dresses, political opinion.

00:13:17.470 --> 00:13:20.307
JS: Yes, length of dresses we didn't try.

00:13:20.331 --> 00:13:22.388
CA: What sort of things?

00:13:22.412 --> 00:13:23.570
JS: Well, everything.

00:13:23.594 --> 00:13:26.858
Everything is grist for the mill --
except hem lengths.

00:13:28.810 --> 00:13:31.110
Weather, annual reports,

00:13:31.134 --> 00:13:35.866
quarterly reports, historic data itself,
volumes, you name it.

00:13:35.890 --> 00:13:37.041
Whatever there is.

00:13:37.065 --> 00:13:39.686
We take in terabytes of data a day.

00:13:39.710 --> 00:13:43.834
And store it away and massage it
and get it ready for analysis.

00:13:45.404 --> 00:13:46.786
You're looking for anomalies.

00:13:46.810 --> 00:13:49.763
You're looking for -- like you said,

00:13:49.787 --> 00:13:52.239
the efficient market
hypothesis is not correct.

00:13:52.263 --> 00:13:55.730
CA: But any one anomaly
might be just a random thing.

00:13:55.754 --> 00:13:59.412
So, is the secret here to just look
at multiple strange anomalies,

00:13:59.436 --> 00:14:00.764
and see when they align?

00:14:01.196 --> 00:14:04.409
JS: Any one anomaly
might be a random thing;

00:14:04.433 --> 00:14:07.472
however, if you have enough data
you can tell that it's not.

00:14:07.496 --> 00:14:12.446
You can see an anomaly that's persistent
for a sufficiently long time --

00:14:12.470 --> 00:14:17.445
the probability of it being
random is not high.

00:14:17.469 --> 00:14:22.327
But these things fade after a while;
anomalies can get washed out.

00:14:22.351 --> 00:14:24.771
So you have to keep on top
of the business.

00:14:24.795 --> 00:14:27.467
CA: A lot of people look
at the hedge fund industry now

00:14:27.491 --> 00:14:31.889
and are sort of ... shocked by it,

00:14:31.913 --> 00:14:34.085
by how much wealth is created there,

00:14:34.109 --> 00:14:36.354
and how much talent is going into it.

00:14:37.481 --> 00:14:41.487
Do you have any worries
about that industry,

00:14:41.511 --> 00:14:43.925
and perhaps the financial
industry in general?

00:14:43.949 --> 00:14:46.653
Kind of being on a runaway train that's --

00:14:46.677 --> 00:14:50.707
I don't know --
helping increase inequality?

00:14:50.731 --> 00:14:54.562
How would you champion what's happening
in the hedge fund industry?

00:14:54.586 --> 00:14:57.194
JS: I think in the last
three or four years,

00:14:57.218 --> 00:14:59.321
hedge funds have not done especially well.

00:14:59.345 --> 00:15:00.745
We've done dandy,

00:15:00.769 --> 00:15:04.770
but the hedge fund industry as a whole
has not done so wonderfully.

00:15:04.794 --> 00:15:09.696
The stock market has been on a roll,
going up as everybody knows,

00:15:09.720 --> 00:15:13.165
and price-earnings ratios have grown.

00:15:13.189 --> 00:15:16.252
So an awful lot of the wealth
that's been created in the last --

00:15:16.276 --> 00:15:19.626
let's say, five or six years --
has not been created by hedge funds.

00:15:20.416 --> 00:15:23.637
People would ask me,
"What's a hedge fund?"

00:15:23.661 --> 00:15:25.921
And I'd say, "One and 20."

00:15:25.945 --> 00:15:29.511
Which means -- now it's two and 20 --

00:15:29.535 --> 00:15:32.888
it's two percent fixed fee
and 20 percent of profits.

00:15:32.912 --> 00:15:35.264
Hedge funds are all
different kinds of creatures.

00:15:35.288 --> 00:15:38.527
CA: Rumor has it you charge
slightly higher fees than that.

00:15:39.297 --> 00:15:42.378
JS: We charged the highest fees
in the world at one time.

00:15:42.402 --> 00:15:45.628
Five and 44, that's what we charge.

00:15:45.652 --> 00:15:47.050
CA: Five and 44.

00:15:47.074 --> 00:15:50.308
So five percent flat,
44 percent of upside.

00:15:50.332 --> 00:15:53.115
You still made your investors
spectacular amounts of money.

00:15:53.139 --> 00:15:54.591
JS: We made good returns, yes.

00:15:54.615 --> 00:15:57.615
People got very mad:
"How can you charge such high fees?"

00:15:57.639 --> 00:15:59.266
I said, "OK, you can withdraw."

00:15:59.290 --> 00:16:02.108
But "How can I get more?"
was what people were --

00:16:02.132 --> 00:16:03.636
(Laughter)

00:16:03.660 --> 00:16:06.100
But at a certain point,
as I think I told you,

00:16:06.124 --> 00:16:11.299
we bought out all the investors
because there's a capacity to the fund.

00:16:11.323 --> 00:16:14.027
CA: But should we worry
about the hedge fund industry

00:16:14.051 --> 00:16:19.489
attracting too much of the world's
great mathematical and other talent

00:16:19.513 --> 00:16:22.751
to work on that, as opposed
to the many other problems in the world?

00:16:22.775 --> 00:16:24.704
JS: Well, it's not just mathematical.

00:16:24.728 --> 00:16:27.407
We hire astronomers and physicists
and things like that.

00:16:27.791 --> 00:16:30.222
I don't think we should worry
about it too much.

00:16:30.246 --> 00:16:33.388
It's still a pretty small industry.

00:16:33.412 --> 00:16:39.409
And in fact, bringing science
into the investing world

00:16:39.433 --> 00:16:41.592
has improved that world.

00:16:41.616 --> 00:16:45.686
It's reduced volatility.
It's increased liquidity.

00:16:45.710 --> 00:16:48.899
Spreads are narrower because
people are trading that kind of stuff.

00:16:48.923 --> 00:16:53.999
So I'm not too worried about Einstein
going off and starting a hedge fund.

00:16:54.436 --> 00:16:58.600
CA: You're at a phase in your life now
where you're actually investing, though,

00:16:58.624 --> 00:17:02.358
at the other end of the supply chain --

00:17:02.382 --> 00:17:06.486
you're actually boosting
mathematics across America.

00:17:06.510 --> 00:17:08.375
This is your wife, Marilyn.

00:17:08.399 --> 00:17:13.155
You're working on
philanthropic issues together.

00:17:13.179 --> 00:17:14.342
Tell me about that.

00:17:14.366 --> 00:17:18.015
JS: Well, Marilyn started --

00:17:18.039 --> 00:17:21.486
there she is up there,
my beautiful wife --

00:17:21.510 --> 00:17:24.482
she started the foundation
about 20 years ago.

00:17:24.506 --> 00:17:25.657
I think '94.

00:17:25.681 --> 00:17:27.776
I claim it was '93, she says it was '94,

00:17:27.800 --> 00:17:30.371
but it was one of those two years.

00:17:30.395 --> 00:17:32.530
(Laughter)

00:17:32.554 --> 00:17:39.273
We started the foundation,
just as a convenient way to give charity.

00:17:40.304 --> 00:17:42.811
She kept the books, and so on.

00:17:42.835 --> 00:17:49.549
We did not have a vision at that time,
but gradually a vision emerged --

00:17:49.573 --> 00:17:55.077
which was to focus on math and science,
to focus on basic research.

00:17:55.527 --> 00:17:58.299
And that's what we've done.

00:17:58.323 --> 00:18:04.678
Six years ago or so, I left Renaissance
and went to work at the foundation.

00:18:04.702 --> 00:18:06.273
So that's what we do.

00:18:06.297 --> 00:18:09.206
CA: And so Math for America
is basically investing

00:18:09.230 --> 00:18:11.868
in math teachers around the country,

00:18:11.892 --> 00:18:15.694
giving them some extra income,
giving them support and coaching.

00:18:15.718 --> 00:18:18.769
And really trying
to make that more effective

00:18:18.793 --> 00:18:21.394
and make that a calling
to which teachers can aspire.

00:18:21.418 --> 00:18:26.208
JS: Yeah -- instead of beating up
the bad teachers,

00:18:26.232 --> 00:18:31.085
which has created morale problems
all through the educational community,

00:18:31.109 --> 00:18:33.550
in particular in math and science,

00:18:33.574 --> 00:18:39.704
we focus on celebrating the good ones
and giving them status.

00:18:39.728 --> 00:18:42.659
Yeah, we give them extra money,
15,000 dollars a year.

00:18:42.683 --> 00:18:47.150
We have 800 math and science teachers
in New York City in public schools today,

00:18:47.174 --> 00:18:48.988
as part of a core.

00:18:49.012 --> 00:18:52.698
There's a great morale among them.

00:18:52.722 --> 00:18:55.228
They're staying in the field.

00:18:55.252 --> 00:18:58.147
Next year, it'll be 1,000
and that'll be 10 percent

00:18:58.171 --> 00:19:01.715
of the math and science teachers
in New York [City] public schools.

00:19:01.739 --> 00:19:07.644
(Applause)

00:19:07.668 --> 00:19:11.078
CA: Jim, here's another project
that you've supported philanthropically:

00:19:11.102 --> 00:19:13.499
Research into origins of life, I guess.

00:19:13.523 --> 00:19:14.970
What are we looking at here?

00:19:15.494 --> 00:19:17.376
JS: Well, I'll save that for a second.

00:19:17.400 --> 00:19:19.562
And then I'll tell you
what you're looking at.

00:19:19.586 --> 00:19:22.642
Origins of life is a fascinating question.

00:19:22.666 --> 00:19:24.199
How did we get here?

00:19:25.128 --> 00:19:26.899
Well, there are two questions:

00:19:26.923 --> 00:19:32.791
One is, what is the route
from geology to biology --

00:19:32.815 --> 00:19:34.196
how did we get here?

00:19:34.220 --> 00:19:36.584
And the other question is,
what did we start with?

00:19:36.608 --> 00:19:39.710
What material, if any,
did we have to work with on this route?

00:19:39.734 --> 00:19:42.795
Those are two very,
very interesting questions.

00:19:43.731 --> 00:19:49.565
The first question is a tortuous path
from geology up to RNA

00:19:49.589 --> 00:19:51.847
or something like that --
how did that all work?

00:19:51.871 --> 00:19:54.259
And the other,
what do we have to work with?

00:19:54.283 --> 00:19:56.054
Well, more than we think.

00:19:56.078 --> 00:20:00.921
So what's pictured there
is a star in formation.

00:20:01.794 --> 00:20:05.219
Now, every year in our Milky Way,
which has 100 billion stars,

00:20:05.243 --> 00:20:07.738
about two new stars are created.

00:20:07.762 --> 00:20:10.232
Don't ask me how, but they're created.

00:20:10.256 --> 00:20:13.336
And it takes them about a million
years to settle out.

00:20:14.090 --> 00:20:16.266
So, in steady state,

00:20:16.290 --> 00:20:20.138
there are about two million stars
in formation at any time.

00:20:20.162 --> 00:20:23.620
That one is somewhere
along this settling-down period.

00:20:24.025 --> 00:20:26.961
And there's all this crap
sort of circling around it,

00:20:26.985 --> 00:20:28.483
dust and stuff.

00:20:29.437 --> 00:20:32.460
And it'll form probably a solar system,
or whatever it forms.

00:20:32.484 --> 00:20:34.660
But here's the thing --

00:20:34.684 --> 00:20:41.032
in this dust that surrounds a forming star

00:20:41.056 --> 00:20:47.091
have been found, now,
significant organic molecules.

00:20:47.916 --> 00:20:54.055
Molecules not just like methane,
but formaldehyde and cyanide --

00:20:54.079 --> 00:21:00.596
things that are the building blocks --
the seeds, if you will -- of life.

00:21:01.094 --> 00:21:03.786
So, that may be typical.

00:21:04.353 --> 00:21:11.287
And it may be typical
that planets around the universe

00:21:11.311 --> 00:21:14.923
start off with some of these
basic building blocks.

00:21:15.788 --> 00:21:18.503
Now does that mean
there's going to be life all around?

00:21:18.527 --> 00:21:19.891
Maybe.

00:21:19.915 --> 00:21:24.042
But it's a question
of how tortuous this path is

00:21:24.066 --> 00:21:28.460
from those frail beginnings,
those seeds, all the way to life.

00:21:28.484 --> 00:21:33.676
And most of those seeds
will fall on fallow planets.

00:21:33.700 --> 00:21:35.109
CA: So for you, personally,

00:21:35.133 --> 00:21:37.855
finding an answer to this question
of where we came from,

00:21:37.879 --> 00:21:41.537
of how did this thing happen,
that is something you would love to see.

00:21:41.561 --> 00:21:43.347
JS: Would love to see.

00:21:43.371 --> 00:21:44.861
And like to know --

00:21:44.885 --> 00:21:50.055
if that path is tortuous enough,
and so improbable,

00:21:50.079 --> 00:21:54.833
that no matter what you start with,
we could be a singularity.

00:21:55.294 --> 00:21:56.446
But on the other hand,

00:21:56.470 --> 00:21:59.948
given all this organic dust
that's floating around,

00:21:59.972 --> 00:22:03.763
we could have lots of friends out there.

00:22:04.905 --> 00:22:06.066
It'd be great to know.

00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:09.570
CA: Jim, a couple of years ago,
I got the chance to speak with Elon Musk,

00:22:09.594 --> 00:22:12.431
and I asked him the secret of his success,

00:22:12.455 --> 00:22:16.146
and he said taking
physics seriously was it.

00:22:16.654 --> 00:22:20.657
Listening to you, what I hear you saying
is taking math seriously,

00:22:20.681 --> 00:22:23.684
that has infused your whole life.

00:22:24.081 --> 00:22:28.644
It's made you an absolute fortune,
and now it's allowing you to invest

00:22:28.668 --> 00:22:33.164
in the futures of thousands and thousands
of kids across America and elsewhere.

00:22:33.525 --> 00:22:36.383
Could it be that science actually works?

00:22:36.407 --> 00:22:39.179
That math actually works?

00:22:39.203 --> 00:22:43.575
JS: Well, math certainly works.
Math certainly works.

00:22:43.599 --> 00:22:44.797
But this has been fun.

00:22:44.821 --> 00:22:49.767
Working with Marilyn and giving it away
has been very enjoyable.

00:22:49.791 --> 00:22:52.727
CA: I just find it --
it's an inspirational thought to me,

00:22:52.751 --> 00:22:56.758
that by taking knowledge seriously,
so much more can come from it.

00:22:56.782 --> 00:22:59.800
So thank you for your amazing life,
and for coming here to TED.

00:22:59.824 --> 00:23:00.575
Thank you.

00:23:00.609 --> 00:23:01.710
Jim Simons!

00:23:01.764 --> 00:23:06.144
(Applause)
